| Coordinates: [42°42′N 23°20′E﻿ / ﻿42.70°N 23.33°E﻿ / 42.70; 23.33](https://geohack.toolforge.org/geohack.php?pagename=Sofia&params=42.7_N_23.33_E_type:city_region:BG) ||

**Sofia** ^[\[a\]](#cite_note-19)^ is the [capital](/wiki/Capital_city "Capital city") and [largest city](/wiki/List_of_cities_and_towns_in_Bulgaria "List of cities and towns in Bulgaria") of [Bulgaria](/wiki/Bulgaria "Bulgaria"). It is situated in the [Sofia Valley](/wiki/Sofia_Valley "Sofia Valley") at the foot of the [Vitosha](/wiki/Vitosha "Vitosha") mountain, in the western part of the country. The city is built west of the [Iskar](/wiki/Iskar_(river) "Iskar (river)") river and has many mineral springs, such as the [Sofia Central Mineral Baths](/wiki/Sofia_Central_Mineral_Baths "Sofia Central Mineral Baths"). It has a [humid continental climate](/wiki/Humid_continental_climate "Humid continental climate"). Being in the centre of the [Balkans](/wiki/Balkans "Balkans"), it is midway between the [Black Sea](/wiki/Black_Sea "Black Sea") and the [Adriatic Sea](/wiki/Adriatic_Sea "Adriatic Sea") and closest to the [Aegean Sea](/wiki/Aegean_Sea "Aegean Sea").^[\[19\]](#cite_note-tr-20)^^[\[20\]](#cite_note-21)^{#cite_ref-21}

Known as Serdica in [antiquity](/wiki/Late_antiquity "Late antiquity") and Sredets in the [Middle Ages](/wiki/Middle_Ages "Middle Ages"), Sofia has been an area of [human habitation](/wiki/List_of_oldest_continuously_inhabited_cities "List of oldest continuously inhabited cities") since at least 7000 BC. The recorded history of the city begins with the attestation of the conquest of Serdica by the [Roman Republic](/wiki/Roman_Republic "Roman Republic") in 29 BC from the [Celtic](/wiki/Celtic_settlement_of_Southeast_Europe "Celtic settlement of Southeast Europe") tribe [Serdi](/wiki/Serdi "Serdi"). During the decline of the [Roman Empire](/wiki/Roman_Empire "Roman Empire"), the city was raided by [Huns](/wiki/Huns "Huns"), [Visigoths](/wiki/Visigoths "Visigoths"), [Avars](/wiki/Pannonian_Avars "Pannonian Avars"), and [Slavs](/wiki/Slavs "Slavs"). In 809, Serdica was incorporated into the [Bulgarian Empire](/wiki/First_Bulgarian_Empire "First Bulgarian Empire") by [Khan](/wiki/Khan_(title) "Khan (title)") [Krum](/wiki/Krum "Krum") and became known as Sredets. In 1018, the [Byzantines](/wiki/Byzantine_Empire "Byzantine Empire") ended Bulgarian rule until 1194, when it was reincorporated by the [reborn Bulgarian Empire](/wiki/Second_Bulgarian_Empire "Second Bulgarian Empire"). Sredets became a major administrative, economic, cultural and literary hub until its conquest by the [Ottomans](/wiki/Ottoman_Empire "Ottoman Empire") in 1382. From 1530 to 1836, Sofia was the regional capital of [Rumelia Eyalet](/wiki/Rumelia_Eyalet "Rumelia Eyalet"), the Ottoman Empire's key province in Europe. Bulgarian rule was restored in 1878. Sofia was selected as the capital of the [Third Bulgarian State](/wiki/Principality_of_Bulgaria "Principality of Bulgaria") in the next year, ushering a period of intense demographic and economic growth.

Sofia is the [14th-largest city in the European Union](/wiki/List_of_cities_in_the_European_Union_by_population_within_city_limits "List of cities in the European Union by population within city limits"). It is surrounded by mountainsides, such as [Vitosha](/wiki/Vitosha "Vitosha") by the southern side, [Lyulin](/wiki/Lyulin_Mountain "Lyulin Mountain") by the western side, and the [Balkan Mountains](/wiki/Balkan_Mountains "Balkan Mountains") by the north, which makes it the [third highest European capital](/wiki/List_of_capital_cities_by_elevation "List of capital cities by elevation") after [Andorra la Vella](/wiki/Andorra_la_Vella "Andorra la Vella") and [Madrid](/wiki/Madrid "Madrid"). Being Bulgaria's primary city, Sofia is home of many of the major local universities, cultural institutions and commercial companies.^[\[21\]](#cite_note-22)^ The city has been described as the "triangle of religious tolerance". This is because three temples of three major world religions---[Christianity](/wiki/Christianity "Christianity"), [Islam](/wiki/Islam "Islam") and [Judaism](/wiki/Judaism "Judaism")---are situated close together: [Sveta Nedelya Church](/wiki/St_Nedelya_Church "St Nedelya Church"), [Banya Bashi Mosque](/wiki/Banya_Bashi_Mosque "Banya Bashi Mosque") and [Sofia Synagogue](/wiki/Sofia_Synagogue "Sofia Synagogue").^[\[22\]](#cite_note-23)^ This triangle was recently expanded to a "square" and includes the Catholic [Cathedral of St Joseph](/wiki/Cathedral_of_St_Joseph,_Sofia "Cathedral of St Joseph, Sofia").^[\[23\]](#cite_note-24)^{#cite_ref-24}

Sofia has been named one of the top ten best places for [startup businesses](/wiki/Startup_company "Startup company") in the world, especially in information technologies.^[\[24\]](#cite_note-25)^ It was Europe's most affordable capital to visit in 2013.^[\[25\]](#cite_note-26)^ The [Boyana Church](/wiki/Boyana_Church "Boyana Church") in Sofia, constructed during the [Second Bulgarian Empire](/wiki/Second_Bulgarian_Empire "Second Bulgarian Empire") and holding much patrimonial symbolism to the [Bulgarian Orthodox Church](/wiki/Bulgarian_Orthodox_Church "Bulgarian Orthodox Church"), was included onto the [World Heritage List](/wiki/World_Heritage_Site "World Heritage Site") in 1979. With its cultural significance in [Southeast Europe](/wiki/Southeast_Europe "Southeast Europe"), Sofia is home to the [National Opera and Ballet of Bulgaria](/wiki/National_Opera_and_Ballet_of_Bulgaria "National Opera and Ballet of Bulgaria"), the [National Palace of Culture](/wiki/National_Palace_of_Culture "National Palace of Culture"), the [Vasil Levski National Stadium](/wiki/Vasil_Levski_National_Stadium "Vasil Levski National Stadium"), the [Ivan Vazov National Theatre](/wiki/Ivan_Vazov_National_Theatre "Ivan Vazov National Theatre"), the [National Archaeological Museum](/wiki/National_Archaeological_Museum,_Bulgaria "National Archaeological Museum, Bulgaria"), and the [Serdica Amphitheatre](/wiki/Amphitheatre_of_Serdica "Amphitheatre of Serdica"). The [Museum of Socialist Art](/wiki/Museum_of_Socialist_Art,_Sofia "Museum of Socialist Art, Sofia") includes many sculptures and posters that educate visitors about the lifestyle in [communist Bulgaria](/wiki/People%27s_Republic_of_Bulgaria "People's Republic of Bulgaria").^[\[26\]](#cite_note-27)^{#cite_ref-27}

The population of Sofia declined from 70,000 in the late 18th century, through 19,000 in 1870, to 11,649 in 1878, after which it began increasing.^[\[27\]](#cite_note-isotriq-28)^ Sofia hosts some 1.28 million^[\[10\]](#cite_note-population-10)^ residents within a territory of 500 km^2^,^[\[28\]](#cite_note-area_total-29)^ a concentration of 17.9% of the country population within the 200th percentile of the country territory. The urban area of Sofia hosts some 1.54 million^[\[29\]](#cite_note-Urban_area_populaton_-_Budapest-30)^ residents within 5723 km^2^, which comprises [Sofia City Province](/wiki/Sofia_City_Province "Sofia City Province") and parts of [Sofia Province](/wiki/Sofia_Province "Sofia Province") ([Dragoman](/wiki/Dragoman_Municipality "Dragoman Municipality"), Names {#Names}
--------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sofia&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: Names")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Sredets_seal_1878.jpg/220px-Sredets_seal_1878.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sredets_seal_1878.jpg) The first seal of the city, from 1878, which calls it *Sredets,* its name in [Old Bulgarian](/wiki/Old_Church_Slavonic "Old Church Slavonic")

For a long time, the city possessed^[\[31\]](#cite_note-constantine-32)^ a [Thracian](/wiki/Thracian_language "Thracian language") name, **Serdica** ([Ancient Greek](/wiki/Ancient_Greek_language "Ancient Greek language"): Σερδικη, *Serdikē* , or Σαρδικη, *Sardikē* ; [Latin](/wiki/Latin_language "Latin language"): *Serdica* or *Sardica*), derived from the tribe *[Serdi](/wiki/Serdi "Serdi")*, who were either of [Thracian](/wiki/Thracians "Thracians"),^[\[17\]](#cite_note-britannica.com-17)^^[\[19\]](#cite_note-tr-20)^ [Celtic](/wiki/Celts "Celts"),^[\[32\]](#cite_note-The_Cambridge_Ancient_History_1992,_page_600-33)^ or mixed Thracian-Celtic origin.^[\[33\]](#cite_note-34)^^[\[34\]](#cite_note-35)^ The emperor [Marcus Ulpius Traianus](/wiki/Trajan "Trajan") (53--117 AD) gave the city the combinative name of *[Ulpia](/wiki/Ulpia_gens "Ulpia gens") Serdica* ;^[\[35\]](#cite_note-world-36)^^[\[36\]](#cite_note-books.google.bg-37)^ Ulpia may be derived from an Umbrian cognate of the [Latin](/wiki/Latin "Latin") word *lupus* , meaning "wolf"^[\[37\]](#cite_note-38)^ or from the Latin *vulpes* (fox). It seems that the first written mention of *Serdica* was made during his reign and the last mention was in the 19th century in a Bulgarian text (Сардакіи, *Sardaki* ). Other names given to Sofia, such as **Serdonpolis** ([Byzantine](/wiki/Byzantine_Greek_language "Byzantine Greek language") [Ancient Greek](/wiki/Ancient_Greek_language "Ancient Greek language"): Σερδών πόλις, "City of the Serdi") and **Triaditza** (Τριάδιτζα, "Trinity"), were mentioned by [Byzantine](/wiki/Byzantine_Empire "Byzantine Empire") [Greek](/wiki/Greek_language "Greek language") sources or coins. The Slavic name **Sredets** ([Church Slavonic](/wiki/Church_Slavonic_language "Church Slavonic language"): Срѣдецъ), which is related to "middle" (среда, "sreda") and to the city's earliest name, first appeared on paper in an 11th-century text. The city was called *Atralisa* by the Arab traveller [Idrisi](/wiki/Muhammad_al-Idrisi "Muhammad al-Idrisi") and *Strelisa* , *Stralitsa* , or *Stralitsion* by the [Crusaders](/wiki/Crusaders "Crusaders").^[\[38\]](#cite_note-39)^{#cite_ref-39}

The name *Sofia* comes from the [Saint Sofia Church](/wiki/Saint_Sofia_Church,_Sofia "Saint Sofia Church, Sofia"),^[\[39\]](#cite_note-40)^ as opposed to the prevailing [Slavic](/wiki/Slavic_languages "Slavic languages") [origin of Bulgarian cities and towns](/wiki/List_of_Bulgaria_province_name_etymologies "List of Bulgaria province name etymologies"). The origin is in the Greek word *[sophía](/wiki/Sophia_(wisdom) "Sophia (wisdom)")* (σοφία, "wisdom"). The earliest works where this latest name is registered are the duplicate of the Gospel of Serdica, in a dialogue between two salesmen from [Dubrovnik](/wiki/Dubrovnik "Dubrovnik") around 1359, in the 14th-century Vitosha Charter of Bulgarian tsar [Ivan Shishman](/wiki/Ivan_Shishman_of_Bulgaria "Ivan Shishman of Bulgaria") and in a [Ragusan](/wiki/Republic_of_Ragusa "Republic of Ragusa") merchant's notes of 1376.^[\[40\]](#cite_note-41)^ In these documents, the city is called *Sofia* ,^\[*[clarification needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify "Wikipedia:Please clarify")*\]^ but, at the same time, the region and the city's inhabitants are still called *Sredecheski* ([Church Slavonic](/wiki/Church_Slavonic_language "Church Slavonic language"): срѣдечьскои, "of Sredets"), which continued until the 20th century. The [Ottomans](/wiki/Ottoman_Empire "Ottoman Empire") came to favour the name **Sofya** ([صوفيه](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D8%B5%D9%88%D9%81%D9%8A%D9%87 "wikt:صوفيه")). In 1879, there was a dispute about what the name of the new Bulgarian capital should be, when the citizens created a committee of famous people, insisting for the Slavic name. Gradually, a compromise arose, officialisation of *Sofia* for the nationwide institutions, while legitimating the title *Sredets* for the administrative and church institutions, before the latter was abandoned through the years.^[\[41\]](#cite_note-42)^{#cite_ref-42}  

Geography {#Geography}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sofia&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section: Geography")\]

[Sofia City Province](/wiki/Sofia_City_Province "Sofia City Province") has an area of 1344 km^2^,^[\[42\]](#cite_note-43)^ while the surrounding and much bigger [Sofia Province](/wiki/Sofia_Province "Sofia Province") is 7,059 km^2^. Sofia's development as a significant settlement owes much to its central position in the [Balkans](/wiki/Balkans "Balkans"). It is situated in western Bulgaria, at the northern foot of the [Vitosha](/wiki/Vitosha "Vitosha") mountain, in the [Sofia Valley](/wiki/Sofia_Valley "Sofia Valley") that is surrounded by the [Balkan mountains](/wiki/Balkan_mountains "Balkan mountains") to the north. The valley has an average altitude of 550 metres (1,800 ft). Sofia is the second highest capital of the [European Union](/wiki/European_Union "European Union") (after [Madrid](/wiki/Madrid "Madrid")) and the third highest capital of Europe (after [Andorra la Vella](/wiki/Andorra_la_Vella "Andorra la Vella") and Madrid). Unlike most European capitals, Sofia does not straddle any large river, but is surrounded by comparatively high mountains on all sides. Three [mountain passes](/wiki/Mountain_pass "Mountain pass") lead to the city, which have been key roads since antiquity, Vitosha being the watershed between [Black](/wiki/Black_Sea "Black Sea") and [Aegean Seas](/wiki/Aegean_Sea "Aegean Sea").{#cite_ref-43}

A number of shallow rivers cross the city, including the [Boyanska](/wiki/Boyanska_reka "Boyanska reka"), [Vladayska](/wiki/Vladaya_River "Vladaya River") and [Perlovska](/wiki/Perlovska "Perlovska"). The [Iskar River](/wiki/Iskar_(river) "Iskar (river)") in its upper course flows near eastern Sofia. It takes its source in [Rila](/wiki/Rila "Rila"), Bulgaria's highest mountain,^[\[43\]](#cite_note-Geographic_Dictionary_of_Bulgaria_537-44)^ and enters Sofia Valley near the village of [German](/wiki/German,_Bulgaria "German, Bulgaria"). The Iskar flows north toward the Balkan Mountains, passing between the eastern city suburbs, next to the main building and below the runways of [Sofia Airport](/wiki/Sofia_Airport "Sofia Airport"), and flows out of the Sofia Valley at the town of [Novi Iskar](/wiki/Novi_Iskar "Novi Iskar"), where the scenic [Iskar Gorge](/wiki/Iskar_Gorge "Iskar Gorge") begins.^[\[44\]](#cite_note-Iskar_1-45)^{#cite_ref-Iskar_1_45-0}

The city is known for its 49 [mineral](/wiki/Spring_(hydrosphere) "Spring (hydrosphere)") and [thermal](/wiki/Hot_spring "Hot spring") springs. Artificial and dam lakes were built in the twentieth century.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Sofia-vitosha-kempinski.jpg/200px-Sofia-vitosha-kempinski.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sofia-vitosha-kempinski.jpg)  
Winter panorama of Sofia with [Vitosha](/wiki/Vitosha "Vitosha") in the background

While the 1818 and 1858 earthquakes were intense and destructive, the [2012 Pernik earthquake](/wiki/2012_Pernik_earthquake "2012 Pernik earthquake") occurred west of Sofia with a [moment magnitude](/wiki/Moment_magnitude_scale "Moment magnitude scale") of 5.6 and a much lower Mercalli intensity of VI (*Strong* ). The [2014 Aegean Sea earthquake](/wiki/2014_Aegean_Sea_earthquake "2014 Aegean Sea earthquake") was also noticed in the city.  

### Climate {#Climate}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sofia&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: Climate")\]

Sofia has a [humid continental climate](/wiki/Humid_continental_climate "Humid continental climate") ([Köppen climate classification](/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification "Köppen climate classification") *Dfb* ; *Cfb* if with −3 °C [isotherm](/wiki/Isotherm_(contour_line) "Isotherm (contour line)")) with an average annual temperature of 10.9 °C (51.6 °F).

Winters are relatively cold and snowy. In the coldest days temperatures can drop below −15 °C (5 °F), most notably in January. The lowest recorded temperature is −31.2 °C (−24 °F) (16 January 1893).^[\[45\]](#cite_note-46)^^[\[46\]](#cite_note-47)^ On average, Sofia receives a total snowfall of 98 cm (38.6 in) and 56 days with snow cover.^[\[47\]](#cite_note-48)^ The snowiest recorded winter was 1939/1940 with a total snowfall of 169 cm (66.5 in).^[\[48\]](#cite_note-49)^ The record snow depth is 57 cm (22.4 in) (25 December 2001).^[\[49\]](#cite_note-50)^ The coldest recorded year was 1893 with an average January temperature of −10.4 °C (13 °F) and an annual temperature of 8.2 °C (46.8 °F).^[\[50\]](#cite_note-51)^{#cite_ref-51}

Summers are quite warm and sunny. In summer, the city generally remains slightly cooler than other parts of Bulgaria, due to its higher altitude. However, the city is also subject to heat waves with high temperatures reaching or exceeding 35 °C (95 °F) on the hottest days, particularly in July and August. The highest recorded temperature is 40.2 °C (104 °F) (5 July 2000).^[\[51\]](#cite_note-52)^ The hottest recorded month was July 2012 with an average temperature of 24.8 °C (77 °F).^[\[52\]](#cite_note-53)^ The warmest year on record was 2024 with an annual temperature of 12.5 °C (55 °F).^[\[53\]](#cite_note-54)^{#cite_ref-54}

Springs and autumns in Sofia are usually short with variable and dynamic weather.

The city receives an average precipitation of 625.7 mm (24.63 in) a year, reaching its peak in late spring and early summer when [thunderstorms](/wiki/Thunderstorms "Thunderstorms") are common. The driest recorded year was 2000 with a total precipitation of 304.6 mm (11.99 in), while the wettest year on record was 2014 with a total precipitation of 1,066.6 mm (41.99 in).^[\[54\]](#cite_note-55)^^[\[55\]](#cite_note-56)^{#cite_ref-56}

### Environment {#Environment}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sofia&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: Environment")\]

The geographic position of the Sofia Valley limits the flow of air masses, increasing the chances of air pollution by particulate matter and [nitrogen oxide](/wiki/Nitrogen_oxide "Nitrogen oxide").^[\[66\]](#cite_note-67)^ Solid fuel used for heating and motor vehicle traffic are significant sources of pollutants. Smog thus persists over the city as [temperature inversions](/wiki/Inversion_(meteorology) "Inversion (meteorology)") and the mountains surrounding the city prevent the circulation of air masses.^[\[67\]](#cite_note-SG1-68)^^[\[68\]](#cite_note-AFP-69)^ As a result, air pollution levels in Sofia are some of the highest in Europe.^[\[69\]](#cite_note-NYT1-70)^{#cite_ref-NYT1_70-0}

[Particulate matter](/wiki/Particulate_matter "Particulate matter") concentrations are consistently above the norm.^[\[68\]](#cite_note-AFP-69)^ During the October 2017 -- March 2018 heating season, particulate levels exceeded the norm on 70 occasions;^[\[67\]](#cite_note-SG1-68)^ on 7 January 2018, PM10 levels reached 632 μg/m^3^,^[\[70\]](#cite_note-SG2-71)^ some twelve times the EU norm of 50 μg/m^3^.^[\[71\]](#cite_note-72)^ Even areas with few sources of air pollution, like [Gorna Banya](/wiki/Gorna_Banya "Gorna Banya"), had PM2.5 and PM10 levels above safe thresholds.^[\[70\]](#cite_note-SG2-71)^ In response to hazardous spikes in air pollution, the Municipal Council implemented a variety of measures in January 2018, like more frequent washing of streets.^[\[72\]](#cite_note-73)^ However, a report by the [European Court of Auditors](/wiki/European_Court_of_Auditors "European Court of Auditors") issued in September 2018 revealed that Sofia has not drafted any projects to reduce air pollution from heating. The report also noted that no industrial pollution monitoring stations operate in Sofia, even though industrial facilities are active in the city. A monitoring station on Eagles' Bridge, where some of the highest particulate matter values were measured, was moved away from the location and has measured sharply lower values since then.^[\[73\]](#cite_note-74)^ Particulates are now largely measured by a network of 300 sensors maintained by volunteers since 2017.^[\[67\]](#cite_note-SG1-68)^ The [European Commission](/wiki/European_Commission "European Commission") has taken Bulgaria to court over its failure to curb air pollution.^[\[68\]](#cite_note-AFP-69)^{#cite_ref-AFP_69-2}

### Prehistory and antiquity {#Prehistory_and_antiquity}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sofia&action=edit&section=6 "Edit section: Prehistory and antiquity")\]

The area has a history of nearly 7,000 years,^[\[74\]](#cite_note-plants-75)^ with the great attraction of the hot water springs that still flow abundantly in the centre of the city. The neolithic village in [Slatina](/wiki/Slatina,_Sofia "Slatina, Sofia") dating to the 5th--6th millennium BC is documented.^[\[75\]](#cite_note-76)^ Another neolithic settlement was founded in the 3rd--4th millennium BC near the site of the modern [National Art Gallery](/wiki/National_Art_Gallery_(Bulgaria) "National Art Gallery (Bulgaria)"), which has been the traditional centre of the city ever since.^[\[76\]](#cite_note-sofiaculture.bg-77)^{#cite_ref-sofiaculture.bg_77-0}

The earliest tribes who settled were the [Thracian](/wiki/Thracians "Thracians") [Tilataei](/wiki/Tilataei "Tilataei"). In the 500s BC, the area became part of a Thracian state union, the [Odrysian kingdom](/wiki/Odrysian_kingdom "Odrysian kingdom") from another Thracian tribe the [Odrysses](/wiki/Odrysses "Odrysses").^[\[77\]](#cite_note-78)^{#cite_ref-78}

In 339 BC [Philip II of Macedon](/wiki/Philip_II_of_Macedon "Philip II of Macedon") destroyed and ravaged the town for the first time.^[\[78\]](#cite_note-Routledge-79)^{#cite_ref-Routledge_79-0}

The [Celtic](/wiki/Celts "Celts") tribe [Serdi](/wiki/Serdi "Serdi") gave their name to the city.^[\[79\]](#cite_note-80)^ The earliest mention of the city comes from an [Athenian](/wiki/Athens "Athens") inscription from the 1st century BC, attesting *Astiu ton Serdon* , i.e. city of the Serdi.^[\[80\]](#cite_note-81)^ According to the inscription and to the writings of [Dio Cassius](/wiki/Dio_Cassius "Dio Cassius"), the Roman general [Crassus](/wiki/Crassus "Crassus") subdued the Serdi and behanded the captives.^[\[81\]](#cite_note-82)^{#cite_ref-82}

Dio Cassius, [Pliny the Elder](/wiki/Pliny_the_Elder "Pliny the Elder") and [Ptolemy](/wiki/Ptolemy "Ptolemy") say that in 27--29 BC Crassus attacked the region "Segetike", which is assumed to be Serdica, or the city of the Serdi.^[\[82\]](#cite_note-83)^^[\[83\]](#cite_note-84)^^[\[84\]](#cite_note-85)^ The ancient city is located between [TZUM](/wiki/TZUM_(Sofia) "TZUM (Sofia)"), [Sheraton Hotel](/wiki/Sheraton_Hotel "Sheraton Hotel") and the Presidency.^[\[76\]](#cite_note-sofiaculture.bg-77)^^[\[85\]](#cite_note-86)^ It gradually became the most important Roman city of the region.^[\[35\]](#cite_note-world-36)^^[\[36\]](#cite_note-books.google.bg-37)^ It became a *municipium* during the reign of Emperor [Trajan](/wiki/Trajan "Trajan") (98--117). Serdica expanded, as [turrets](/wiki/Turret_(architecture) "Turret (architecture)"), protective walls, [public baths](/wiki/Public_bathing "Public bathing"), administrative and cult buildings, a civic [basilica](/wiki/Basilica "Basilica"), an [amphitheatre](/wiki/Amphitheatre "Amphitheatre"), a circus, the [City council](/wiki/City_council "City council") (Boulé), a large forum, a big circus (theatre), etc. were built. Serdica was a significant city on the Roman road [Via Militaris](/wiki/Via_Militaris "Via Militaris"), connecting [Singidunum](/wiki/Singidunum "Singidunum") and [Byzantium](/wiki/Byzantium "Byzantium"). In the 3rd century, it became the capital of [Dacia Aureliana](/wiki/Dacia_Aureliana "Dacia Aureliana"),^[\[86\]](#cite_note-87)^ and when Emperor [Diocletian](/wiki/Diocletian "Diocletian") divided the province of Dacia Aureliana into Dacia Ripensis (at the banks of the [Danube](/wiki/Danube "Danube")) and [Dacia Mediterranea](/wiki/Dacia_(Roman_province) "Dacia (Roman province)"), Serdica became the capital of the latter. Serdica's citizens of [Thracian](/wiki/Thracians "Thracians") descent were referred to as [Illyrians](/wiki/Illyrians "Illyrians")^[\[78\]](#cite_note-Routledge-79)^ probably because it was at some time the capital of [Eastern Illyria](/w/index.php?title=Eastern_Illyria&action=edit&redlink=1 "Eastern Illyria (page does not exist)") ([Second Illyria](/w/index.php?title=Second_Illyria&action=edit&redlink=1 "Second Illyria (page does not exist)")).^[\[87\]](#cite_note-88)^{#cite_ref-88}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/20140618_Sofia_09.jpg/220px-20140618_Sofia_09.jpg)](/wiki/File:20140618_Sofia_09.jpg) Dated from the early 4th century, the [Church of Saint George](/wiki/Church_of_Saint_George,_Sofia "Church of Saint George, Sofia") is the oldest standing edifice in Sofia.

Roman emperors [Aurelian](/wiki/Aurelian "Aurelian") (215--275)^[\[88\]](#cite_note-89)^ and [Galerius](/wiki/Galerius "Galerius") (260--311)^[\[89\]](#cite_note-90)^ were born in Serdica.{#cite_ref-90}

The city expanded and became a significant political and economical centre, more so as it became one of the first Roman cities where Christianity was recognised as an [official religion](/wiki/State_religion "State religion") (under [Galerius](/wiki/Galerius "Galerius")). The [Edict of Toleration by Galerius](/wiki/Edict_of_Toleration_by_Galerius "Edict of Toleration by Galerius") was issued in 311 in Serdica by the Roman emperor Galerius, officially ending the Diocletianic persecution of Christianity. The Edict implicitly granted Christianity the status of "[religio licita](/wiki/Religio_licita "Religio licita")", a worship recognised and accepted by the Roman Empire. It was the first edict legalising Christianity, preceding the [Edict of Milan](/wiki/Edict_of_Milan "Edict of Milan") by two years.

Serdica was the capital of the [Diocese of Dacia](/wiki/Diocese_of_Dacia "Diocese of Dacia") (337--602).

For [Constantine the Great](/wiki/Constantine_the_Great "Constantine the Great") it was 'Sardica mea Roma est' (Serdica is my Rome). He considered making Serdica the capital of the [Byzantine Empire](/wiki/Byzantine_Empire "Byzantine Empire") instead of Constantinople.^[\[90\]](#cite_note-91)^ which was already not dissimilar to a [tetrarchic](/wiki/Tetrarchy "Tetrarchy") capital of the Roman Empire.^[\[91\]](#cite_note-92)^ In 343 AD, the [Council of Sardica](/wiki/Council_of_Sardica "Council of Sardica") was held in the city, in a church located where the current 6th century [Church of Saint Sophia](/wiki/Hagia_Sophia_Church_(Sofia) "Hagia Sophia Church (Sofia)") was later built.{#cite_ref-92}

The city was destroyed in the [447 invasion](/wiki/Theodosius_II#Wars_with_the_Huns,_Vandals,_and_Persians "Theodosius II") of the [Huns](/wiki/Huns "Huns") and laid in ruins for a century^[\[78\]](#cite_note-Routledge-79)^ It was rebuilt by [Byzantine Emperor](/wiki/List_of_Byzantine_emperors "List of Byzantine emperors") [Justinian I](/wiki/Justinian_I "Justinian I"). During the reign of Justinian it flourished, being surrounded with great fortress walls whose remnants can still be seen today.{#cite_ref-Routledge_79-2}  

### Middle Ages {#Middle_Ages}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sofia&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: Middle Ages")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Kalojan_desislava.jpg/220px-Kalojan_desislava.jpg)](/wiki/File:Kalojan_desislava.jpg) The 13th century lord of Sredets [Kaloyan](/wiki/Kaloyan_and_Desislava "Kaloyan and Desislava") and his wife Desislava, [Boyana Church](/wiki/Boyana_Church "Boyana Church")

Serdica became part of the [First Bulgarian Empire](/wiki/First_Bulgarian_Empire "First Bulgarian Empire") during the reign of Khan [Krum](/wiki/Krum "Krum") in 809, after a long [siege](/wiki/Siege_of_Serdica_(809) "Siege of Serdica (809)"). The fall of the strategic city prompted a major and ultimately disastrous invasion of Bulgaria by the [Byzantine](/wiki/Byzantine_Empire "Byzantine Empire") emperor [Nikephoros I](/wiki/Nikephoros_I "Nikephoros I"), which led to his demise at the hands of the [Bulgarian army](/wiki/Medieval_Bulgarian_army "Medieval Bulgarian army").^[\[92\]](#cite_note-93)^ In the aftermath of the war, the city was permanently integrated in Bulgaria and became known by the Slavic name of Sredets. It grew into an important fortress and administrative centre under Krum's successor Khan [Omurtag](/wiki/Omurtag_of_Bulgaria "Omurtag of Bulgaria"), who made it a centre of Sredets province (Sredetski komitat, Средецки комитат). The Bulgarian patron saint [John of Rila](/wiki/John_of_Rila "John of Rila") was buried in Sredets by orders of Emperor [Peter I](/wiki/Peter_I_of_Bulgaria "Peter I of Bulgaria") in the mid 10th century.^[\[93\]](#cite_note-stancheva120-94)^ After the conquest of the Bulgarian capital [Preslav](/wiki/Preslav "Preslav") by [Sviatoslav I of Kyiv](/wiki/Sviatoslav_I "Sviatoslav I") and [John I Tzimiskes](/wiki/John_I_Tzimiskes "John I Tzimiskes")' armies in 970--971, the [Bulgarian Patriarch](/wiki/Patriarch_of_All_Bulgaria "Patriarch of All Bulgaria") Damyan chose Sredets for his seat in the next year and the capital of Bulgaria was temporarily moved there.^[\[94\]](#cite_note-95)^ In the second half of 10th century the city was ruled by [Komit Nikola](/wiki/Nicholas_(komes) "Nicholas (komes)") and his sons, known as the "[Komitopuli](/wiki/Cometopuli_dynasty "Cometopuli dynasty")". One of them was [Samuil](/wiki/Samuel_of_Bulgaria "Samuel of Bulgaria"), who was eventually crowned Emperor of Bulgaria in 997. In 986, the Byzantine Emperor [Basil II](/wiki/Basil_II "Basil II") laid siege to Sredets but after 20 days of fruitless assaults the garrison broke out and forced the Byzantines to abandon the campaign. On his way to Constantinople, Basil II was ambushed and soundly defeated by the Bulgarians in the [battle of the Gates of Trajan](/wiki/Battle_of_the_Gates_of_Trajan "Battle of the Gates of Trajan").^[\[93\]](#cite_note-stancheva120-94)^^[\[95\]](#cite_note-96)^{#cite_ref-96}

The city eventually fell to the [Byzantine Empire](/wiki/Byzantine_Empire "Byzantine Empire") in 1018, following the [Byzantine conquest of Bulgaria](/wiki/Byzantine_conquest_of_Bulgaria "Byzantine conquest of Bulgaria"). Sredets joined the [uprising of Peter Delyan](/wiki/Uprising_of_Peter_Delyan "Uprising of Peter Delyan") in 1040--1041 in a failed attempt to restore Bulgarian independence and was the last stronghold of the rebels, led by the local commander Botko.^[\[96\]](#cite_note-97)^ During the 11th century many [Pechenegs](/wiki/Pechenegs "Pechenegs") were settled down in Sofia region as Byzantine federats.{#cite_ref-97}

It was once again incorporated into the [restored Bulgarian Empire](/wiki/Second_Bulgarian_Empire "Second Bulgarian Empire") in 1194 at the time of Emperor [Ivan Asen I](/wiki/Ivan_Asen_I_of_Bulgaria "Ivan Asen I of Bulgaria") and became a major administrative and cultural centre.^[\[97\]](#cite_note-98)^ Several of the city's governors were members of the Bulgarian imperial family and held the title of *[sebastokrator](/wiki/Sebastokrator "Sebastokrator")* , the second highest at the time, after the [tsar](/wiki/Tsar "Tsar"). Some known holders of the title were [Kaloyan](/wiki/Kaloyan_(sebastocrator) "Kaloyan (sebastocrator)"), [Peter](/wiki/Peter_(sevastokrator) "Peter (sevastokrator)") and their relative Aleksandar Asen (d. after 1232), a son of [Ivan Asen I of Bulgaria](/wiki/Ivan_Asen_I_of_Bulgaria "Ivan Asen I of Bulgaria") ( 1189--1196). In the 13th and 14th centuries Sredets was an important spiritual and literary hub with a cluster of 14 monasteries in its vicinity, that were eventually destroyed by the Ottomans. The city produced multicolored sgraffito ceramics, jewelry and ironware.^[\[98\]](#cite_note-99)^{#cite_ref-99}

In 1382/1383 or 1385, Sredets was seized by the [Ottoman Empire](/wiki/Ottoman_Empire "Ottoman Empire") in the course of the [Bulgarian-Ottoman Wars](/wiki/Bulgarian%E2%80%93Ottoman_Wars "Bulgarian–Ottoman Wars") by [Lala Şahin Pasha](/wiki/Lala_%C5%9Eahin_Pasha "Lala Şahin Pasha"), following a [three-month siege](/wiki/Siege_of_Sofia "Siege of Sofia").^[\[99\]](#cite_note-:0-100)^ The Ottoman commander left the following description of the city garrison: "Inside the fortress \[Sofia\] there is a large and elite army, its soldiers are heavily built, moustached and look war-hardened, but are used to consume wine and [rakia](/wiki/Rakia "Rakia")---in a word, jolly fellows."^[\[100\]](#cite_note-101)^{#cite_ref-101}  

### Early modern history {#Early_modern_history}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sofia&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: Early modern history")\]

From the 14th century till the 19th century Sofia was an important administrative center in the Ottoman Empire. It became the capital of the [beylerbeylik](/wiki/Beylerbey "Beylerbey") of [Rumelia](/wiki/Rumelia "Rumelia") ([Rumelia Eyalet](/wiki/Rumelia_Eyalet "Rumelia Eyalet")), the [province](/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_the_Ottoman_Empire "Administrative divisions of the Ottoman Empire") that administered the Ottoman lands in [Europe](/wiki/Europe "Europe") (the [Balkans](/wiki/Balkans "Balkans")), one of the two together with the beylerbeylik of [Anatolia](/wiki/Anatolia "Anatolia"). It was the capital of the important [Sanjak of Sofia](/wiki/Sanjak_of_Sofia "Sanjak of Sofia") as well, including the whole of [Thrace](/wiki/Thrace "Thrace") with [Plovdiv](/wiki/Plovdiv "Plovdiv") and [Edirne](/wiki/Edirne "Edirne"), and part of [Macedonia](/wiki/Macedonia_(region) "Macedonia (region)") with [Thessaloniki](/wiki/Thessaloniki "Thessaloniki") and [Skopje](/wiki/Skopje "Skopje").^[\[101\]](#cite_note-102)^{#cite_ref-102}

During the initial stages of the [Crusade of Varna](/wiki/Crusade_of_Varna "Crusade of Varna") in 1443, it was occupied by Hungarian forces for a short time in 1443, and the Bulgarian population celebrated a mass [Saint Sofia Church](/wiki/Saint_Sofia_Church,_Sofia "Saint Sofia Church, Sofia"). Following the defeat of the crusader forces in 1444, the city's Christians faced persecution. In 1530 Sofia became the capital of the [Ottoman province](/wiki/Subdivisions_of_the_Ottoman_Empire "Subdivisions of the Ottoman Empire") (beylerbeylik) of [Rumelia](/wiki/Rumelia "Rumelia") for about three centuries. During that time Sofia was the largest import-export-base in modern-day Bulgaria for the caravan trade with the [Republic of Ragusa](/wiki/Republic_of_Ragusa "Republic of Ragusa"). In the 15th and 16th century, Sofia was expanded by Ottoman building activity. Public investments in infrastructure, education and local economy brought greater diversity to the city. Amongst others, the population consisted of [Muslims](/wiki/Muslim "Muslim"), [Bulgarian](/wiki/Bulgarian_language "Bulgarian language") and [Greek](/wiki/Greek_language "Greek language") speaking [Orthodox Christians](/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church "Eastern Orthodox Church"), [Armenians](/wiki/Armenians "Armenians"), [Georgians](/wiki/Georgians "Georgians"), [Catholic](/wiki/Catholic_Church "Catholic Church") Ragusans, Jews ([Romaniote](/wiki/Romaniote_Jews "Romaniote Jews"), [Ashkenazi](/wiki/Ashkenazi_Jews "Ashkenazi Jews") and [Sephardi](/wiki/Sephardi "Sephardi")), and [Romani people](/wiki/Romani_people "Romani people").^[\[99\]](#cite_note-:0-100)^ The 16th century was marked by a wave of persecutions against the Bulgarian Christians, a total of nine became [New Martyrs](/wiki/New_Martyrs "New Martyrs") in Sofia and were sainted by the Orthodox Church, including [George the New](/wiki/George_of_Kratovo "George of Kratovo") (1515), Sophronius of Sofia (1515), George the Newest (1530), [Nicholas of Sofia](/wiki/St._Nicholas_of_Sofia "St. Nicholas of Sofia") (1555) and Terapontius of Sofia (1555).^[\[102\]](#cite_note-103)^{#cite_ref-103}
[![Sofia with the clock tower](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Sofia-oberbauer.png/220px-Sofia-oberbauer.png)](/wiki/File:Sofia-oberbauer.png) Sofia in mid-19th-century

When it comes to the cityscape, 16th century sources mention eight [Friday mosques](/wiki/Jama_Masjid "Jama Masjid"), three public libraries, numerous schools, 12 churches, three synagogues, and the largest [bedesten](/wiki/Bedesten "Bedesten") (market) of the Balkans.^[\[99\]](#cite_note-:0-100)^ Additionally, there were fountains and *[hammams](/wiki/Turkish_bath "Turkish bath")* (bathhouses). Most prominent churches such as Saint Sofia and Saint George were converted into mosques, and a number of new ones were constructed, including [Banya Bashi Mosque](/wiki/Banya_Bashi_Mosque "Banya Bashi Mosque") built by the Ottoman architect [Mimar Sinan](/wiki/Mimar_Sinan "Mimar Sinan"). In total there were 11 big and over 100 small mosques by the 17th century.^[\[103\]](#cite_note-104)^^[\[104\]](#cite_note-105)^ In 1610 the [Vatican](/wiki/Catholic_Church "Catholic Church") established the [See of Sofia](/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Diocese_of_Sofia_and_Plovdiv "Roman Catholic Diocese of Sofia and Plovdiv") for Catholics of [Rumelia](/wiki/Rumelia "Rumelia"), which existed until 1715 when most Catholics had emigrated.^[\[105\]](#cite_note-106)^ There was an important uprising against Ottoman rule in Sofia, [Samokov](/wiki/Samokov "Samokov") and Western Bulgaria in 1737.{#cite_ref-106}

Sofia entered a period of economic and political decline in the 17th century, accelerated during the period of anarchy in the Ottoman Balkans of the late 18th and early 19th century, when local Ottoman warlords ravaged the countryside. 1831 Ottoman population statistics show that 42% of the Christians were non-taxpayers in the [kaza](/wiki/Kaza "Kaza") of Sofia and the amount of middle-class and poor Christians were equal.^[\[106\]](#cite_note-107)^ Since the 18th century the *[beylerbeys](/wiki/Beylerbey "Beylerbey")* of Rumelia often stayed in [Bitola](/wiki/Bitola "Bitola"), which became the official capital of the province in 1826. Sofia remained the seat of a [sanjak](/wiki/Sanjak "Sanjak") (district). By the 19th century the Bulgarian population had two schools and seven churches, contributing to the [Bulgarian National Revival](/wiki/Bulgarian_National_Revival "Bulgarian National Revival"). In 1858 [Nedelya Petkova](/wiki/Nedelya_Petkova "Nedelya Petkova") created the first Bulgarian school for women in the city. In 1867 was inaugurated the first *[chitalishte](/wiki/Chitalishte "Chitalishte")* in Sofia -- a Bulgarian cultural institution. In 1870 the Bulgarian revolutionary [Vasil Levski](/wiki/Vasil_Levski "Vasil Levski") established a [revolutionary committee](/wiki/Internal_Revolutionary_Organization "Internal Revolutionary Organization") in the city and in the neighbouring villages. Following his capture in 1873, Vasil Levski was transferred and hanged in Sofia by the Ottomans.{#cite_ref-107}  

### Modern and contemporary history {#Modern_and_contemporary_history}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sofia&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section: Modern and contemporary history")\]

During the [Russo-Turkish War of 1877--78](/wiki/Russo-Turkish_War_(1877%E2%80%931878) "Russo-Turkish War (1877–1878)"), [Suleiman Pasha](/wiki/Suleiman_Pasha_(Ottoman_general) "Suleiman Pasha (Ottoman general)") threatened to burn the city in defence, but the foreign diplomats Leandre Legay, [Vito Positano](/wiki/Vito_Positano "Vito Positano"), Rabbi Gabriel Almosnino and Josef Valdhart refused to leave the city thus saving it. Many Bulgarian residents of Sofia armed themselves and sided with the Russian forces.^[\[107\]](#cite_note-108)^ Sofia was relieved (see [Battle of Sofia](/wiki/Battle_of_Sofia "Battle of Sofia")) from [Ottoman rule](/wiki/Ottoman_rule_of_Bulgaria "Ottoman rule of Bulgaria") by [Russian forces](/wiki/Imperial_Russian_Army "Imperial Russian Army") under Gen. [Iosif Gurko](/wiki/Iosif_Gurko "Iosif Gurko") on 4 January 1878. It was proposed as a capital by [Marin Drinov](/wiki/Marin_Drinov "Marin Drinov") and was accepted as such on 3 April 1879. By the time of its liberation the population of the city was 11,649.^[\[108\]](#cite_note-109)^{#cite_ref-109}

Most mosques in Sofia were destroyed in that war, seven of them destroyed in one night in December 1878 when a thunderstorm masked the noise of the explosions arranged by Russian military engineers.^[\[109\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrampton2006114-110)^^[\[110\]](#cite_note-111)^ Following the war, the great majority of the Muslim population left Sofia.^[\[99\]](#cite_note-:0-100)^{#cite_ref-:0_100-3}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/376bombgroup-bulgaria-01-jun-1944.gif/220px-376bombgroup-bulgaria-01-jun-1944.gif)](/wiki/File:376bombgroup-bulgaria-01-jun-1944.gif) The [allied bombing of Sofia in World War II](/wiki/Bombing_of_Sofia_in_World_War_II "Bombing of Sofia in World War II") in 1944

For a few decades after the liberation, Sofia experienced large population growth, mainly by migration from other regions of the Principality (Kingdom since 1908) of Bulgaria, and from the still Ottoman [Macedonia](/wiki/Macedonia_(region) "Macedonia (region)") and [Thrace](/wiki/Thrace "Thrace").

In 1900, the first electric lightbulb in the city was turned on.^[\[111\]](#cite_note-112)^{#cite_ref-112}

In the [Second Balkan War](/wiki/Second_Balkan_War "Second Balkan War"), Bulgaria was fighting alone practically all of its neighbouring countries. When the [Romanian Army](/wiki/Romanian_Army "Romanian Army") entered [Vrazhdebna](/wiki/Vrazhdebna "Vrazhdebna") in 1913, then a village 11 kilometres (7 miles) from Sofia, now a suburb,^[\[112\]](#cite_note-Hall97-113)^ this prompted the [Tsardom of Bulgaria](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Bulgaria "Kingdom of Bulgaria") to capitulate.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^ During the war, Sofia was flown by the [Romanian Air Corps](/wiki/Romanian_Air_Corps "Romanian Air Corps"), which engaged on photoreconnaissance operations and threw propaganda pamphlets to the city. Thus, Sofia became the first capital on the world to be overflown by enemy aircraft.^[\[113\]](#cite_note-Hall118-114)^{#cite_ref-Hall118_114-0}

During the [Second World War](/wiki/Military_history_of_Bulgaria_during_World_War_II "Military history of Bulgaria during World War II"), Bulgaria declared war on the US and UK on 13 December 1941 and in late 1943 and early 1944 the [US and UK Air forces conducted bombings over Sofia](/wiki/Bombing_of_Sofia_in_World_War_II "Bombing of Sofia in World War II"). As a consequence of the bombings thousands of buildings were destroyed or damaged including the Capital Library and thousands of books. In 1944 Sofia and the rest of Bulgaria was occupied by the Soviet [Red Army](/wiki/Red_Army "Red Army") and within days of the Soviet invasion Bulgaria declared war on Nazi Germany.

In 1945, the communist [Fatherland Front](/wiki/Fatherland_Front_(Bulgaria) "Fatherland Front (Bulgaria)") took power. The transformations of Bulgaria into the [People's Republic of Bulgaria](/wiki/People%27s_Republic_of_Bulgaria "People's Republic of Bulgaria") in 1946 and into the Republic of Bulgaria in 1990 marked significant changes in the city's appearance. The population of Sofia expanded rapidly due to migration from rural regions. New residential areas were built in the outskirts of the city, like Druzhba, Mladost and Lyulin.

During the [Communist Party](/wiki/Bulgarian_Communist_Party "Bulgarian Communist Party") rule, a number of the city's most emblematic streets and squares were renamed for ideological reasons, with the original names restored after 1989.^[\[114\]](#cite_note-115)^{#cite_ref-115}

The [Georgi Dimitrov Mausoleum](/wiki/Georgi_Dimitrov_Mausoleum "Georgi Dimitrov Mausoleum"), where [Dimitrov's](/wiki/Georgi_Dimitrov "Georgi Dimitrov") body had been preserved in a similar way to the [Lenin mausoleum](/wiki/Lenin_mausoleum "Lenin mausoleum"), was demolished in 1999.  

Cityscape {#Cityscape}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sofia&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section: Cityscape")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Cathedral_Saint_Alexander_Nevsky_%2823997168458%29.jpg/220px-Cathedral_Saint_Alexander_Nevsky_%2823997168458%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Cathedral_Saint_Alexander_Nevsky_(23997168458).jpg) A view over central Sofia, with the [Alexander Nevsky Cathedral](/wiki/Alexander_Nevsky_Cathedral,_Sofia "Alexander Nevsky Cathedral, Sofia") in the foreground and [Vitosha](/wiki/Vitosha "Vitosha") in the distance

In Sofia there are 607,473 dwellings and 101,696 buildings. According to modern records, 39,551 dwellings were constructed until 1949, 119,943 between 1950 and 1969, 287,191 between 1970 and 1989, 57,916 in the 90s and 102,623 between 2000 and 2011. Until 1949, 13,114 buildings were constructed and between 10,000 and 20,000 in each following decade.^[\[115\]](#cite_note-book-116)^ Sofia's architecture combines a wide range of architectural styles, some of which are aesthetically incompatible. These vary from Christian Roman architecture and medieval Bulgarian fortresses to Neoclassicism and prefabricated Socialist-era apartment blocks, as well as newer glass buildings and international architecture. A number of ancient Roman, Byzantine and medieval Bulgarian buildings are preserved in the centre of the city. These include the 4th century [Rotunda of St. George](/wiki/Church_of_St._George,_Sofia "Church of St. George, Sofia"), the walls of the Serdica fortress and the partially preserved [Amphitheatre of Serdica](/wiki/Amphitheatre_of_Serdica "Amphitheatre of Serdica").{#cite_ref-book_116-0}

After the Liberation War, knyaz [Alexander Battenberg](/wiki/Alexander,_Prince_of_Bulgaria "Alexander, Prince of Bulgaria") invited architects from [Austria-Hungary](/wiki/Austria-Hungary "Austria-Hungary") to shape the new capital's architectural appearance.^[\[116\]](#cite_note-Fig._Arts-117)^{#cite_ref-Fig._Arts_117-0}

Among the architects invited to work in Bulgaria were [Friedrich Grünanger](/wiki/Friedrich_Gr%C3%BCnanger "Friedrich Grünanger"), Adolf Václav Kolář, and [Viktor Rumpelmayer](/wiki/Viktor_Rumpelmayer "Viktor Rumpelmayer"), who designed the most important public buildings needed by the newly re-established Bulgarian government, as well as numerous houses for the country's elite.^[\[116\]](#cite_note-Fig._Arts-117)^ Later, many foreign-educated Bulgarian architects also contributed. The architecture of Sofia's centre is thus a combination of [Neo-Baroque](/wiki/Baroque_Revival_architecture "Baroque Revival architecture"), Neo-[Rococo](/wiki/Rococo "Rococo"), [Neo-Renaissance](/wiki/Renaissance_Revival_architecture "Renaissance Revival architecture") and [Neoclassicism](/wiki/Neoclassicism "Neoclassicism"), with the [Vienna Secession](/wiki/Vienna_Secession "Vienna Secession") also later playing an important part, but it is most typically Central European.{#cite_ref-Fig._Arts_117-1}

After World War II and the establishment of a [Communist government](/wiki/Communist_state "Communist state") in Bulgaria in 1944, the architectural style was substantially altered. [Stalinist Gothic](/wiki/Stalinist_architecture "Stalinist architecture") public buildings emerged in the centre, notably the spacious government complex around [The Largo](/wiki/Largo,_Sofia "Largo, Sofia"), Vasil Levski Stadium, the Cyril and Methodius National Library and others. As the city grew outwards, the then-new neighbourhoods were dominated by many concrete [tower blocks](/wiki/Tower_block "Tower block"), prefabricated panel apartment buildings and examples of [Brutalist architecture](/wiki/Brutalist_architecture "Brutalist architecture").

After the abolition of [Communism](/wiki/Communism "Communism") in 1989, Sofia witnessed the construction of whole business districts and neighbourhoods, as well as modern skyscraper-like glass-fronted office buildings, but also top-class residential neighbourhoods. The 126-metre (413 ft) [Capital Fort](/wiki/Capital_Fort "Capital Fort") Business Centre is the first skyscraper in Bulgaria, with its 36 floors. However, the end of the old administration and centrally planned system also paved the way for chaotic and unrestrained construction, which continues today.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/StSophiaChurch-Sofia-10.jpg/220px-StSophiaChurch-Sofia-10.jpg)](/wiki/File:StSophiaChurch-Sofia-10.jpg) Interior of the ancient [Saint Sofia Church](/wiki/Saint_Sofia_Church,_Sofia "Saint Sofia Church, Sofia") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Sofia_%2717_%2824614289157%29_ver_2.jpg/220px-Sofia_%2717_%2824614289157%29_ver_2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sofia_%2717_(24614289157)_ver_2.jpg) [Neoclassical architecture](/wiki/Neoclassical_architecture "Neoclassical architecture"), Polygraphia office center  

### Green areas {#Green_areas}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sofia&action=edit&section=11 "Edit section: Green areas")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Borisova_gradina_autumn.jpg/220px-Borisova_gradina_autumn.jpg)](/wiki/File:Borisova_gradina_autumn.jpg) [Borisova gradina](/wiki/Borisova_gradina "Borisova gradina")

The city has an extensive [green belt](/wiki/Green_belt "Green belt"). Some of the neighbourhoods constructed after 2000 are densely built up and lack green spaces. There are four principal parks -- [Borisova gradina](/wiki/Borisova_gradina "Borisova gradina") in the city centre and the *Southern* , *Western* and *Northern* parks. Several smaller parks, among which the [Vazrazhdane Park](/w/index.php?title=Vazrazhdane_Park&action=edit&redlink=1 "Vazrazhdane Park (page does not exist)"), [Zaimov Park](/w/index.php?title=Zaimov_Park&action=edit&redlink=1 "Zaimov Park (page does not exist)"), [City Garden](/wiki/City_Garden_(Sofia) "City Garden (Sofia)") and the [Doctors' Garden](/wiki/Doctors%27_Garden "Doctors' Garden"), are located in central Sofia. The [Vitosha](/wiki/Vitosha "Vitosha") Nature Park (the oldest [national park](/wiki/National_park "National park") in the [Balkans](/wiki/Balkans "Balkans"))^[\[117\]](#cite_note-118)^ includes most of [Vitosha](/wiki/Vitosha "Vitosha") mountain and covers an area of 266 square kilometres (103 sq mi),^[\[118\]](#cite_note-119)^ with roughly half of it lying within the municipality of Sofia. Vitosha mountain is a popular hiking destination due to its proximity and ease of access via car and public transport. Two functioning cable cars provide year long access from the outskirts of the city. The mountain offers favourable skiing conditions during the winter. During the 1970s and the 1980s multiple ski slopes of varying difficulty were made available. Skiing equipment can be rented and skiing lessons are available. However, due to the bad communication between the private offshore company that runs the resort and Sofia municipality, most of the ski areas have been left to decay in the last 10 years, so that only one chairlift and one slope work.{#cite_ref-119}

[Sofia Municipality](/wiki/Sofia_Capital_Municipality "Sofia Capital Municipality") is identical to [Sofia City Province](/wiki/Sofia_City_Province "Sofia City Province"), which is distinct from [Sofia Province](/wiki/Sofia_Province "Sofia Province"), which surrounds but does not include the capital itself. Besides the city proper, the 24 districts of Sofia Municipality encompass three other towns and 34 villages.^[\[120\]](#cite_note-District_Mayors-121)^ Districts and settlements have their own mayor who is elected in a popular election. The assembly members are chosen every four years. The common head of Sofia Municipality and all the 38 settlements is the [mayor of Sofia](/wiki/List_of_mayors_of_Sofia "List of mayors of Sofia").^[\[120\]](#cite_note-District_Mayors-121)^ The mayor [Vasil Terziev](/wiki/Vasil_Terziev "Vasil Terziev") is serving his first term, having won the [2023 election](/wiki/2023_Sofia_mayoral_election "2023 Sofia mayoral election") as the nominee of the [PP-DB](/wiki/PP-DB "PP-DB") coalition and the local [Save Sofia](/wiki/Spasi_Sofia "Spasi Sofia") party. After winning the first round of the election without receiving the majority of votes, Terziev entered a tight runoff against [BSP](/wiki/Bulgarian_Socialist_Party "Bulgarian Socialist Party") candidate [Vanya Grigorova](/wiki/Vanya_Grigorova "Vanya Grigorova"), which he won with 175,044 votes, compared to Grigorova's 170,258.^[\[121\]](#cite_note-122)^^[\[122\]](#cite_note-123)^{#cite_ref-123}

### National government {#National_government}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sofia&action=edit&section=14 "Edit section: National government")\]

Sofia is the seat of the executive ([Council of Ministers](/wiki/Government_of_Bulgaria "Government of Bulgaria")), [legislative](/wiki/Legislative "Legislative") ([National Assembly](/wiki/National_Assembly_(Bulgaria) "National Assembly (Bulgaria)")) and [judiciary](/wiki/Judiciary "Judiciary") ([Supreme Court](/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Bulgaria "Supreme Court of Bulgaria") and [Constitutional Court](/wiki/Constitutional_Court_of_Bulgaria "Constitutional Court of Bulgaria")) bodies of Bulgaria, as well as all government agencies, ministries, the [National Bank](/wiki/Bulgarian_National_Bank "Bulgarian National Bank"), and the delegation of the [European Commission](/wiki/European_Commission "European Commission"). The [President](/wiki/President_of_Bulgaria "President of Bulgaria"), along with the Council of Ministers, is located on [Independence Square](/wiki/Largo,_Sofia "Largo, Sofia"), also known as The Largo or *The Triangle of Power* .^[\[124\]](#cite_note-125)^ One of the three buildings in the architectural ensemble, the former [Bulgarian Communist Party](/wiki/Bulgarian_Communist_Party "Bulgarian Communist Party") headquarters, is due to become the seat of the Parliament. A refurbishment project is due to be completed in mid-2019,^[\[125\]](#cite_note-126)^ while the [old National Assembly](/wiki/Bulgaria_National_Assembly_Building "Bulgaria National Assembly Building") building will become a museum or will only host ceremonial political events.^[\[126\]](#cite_note-127)^{#cite_ref-127}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/National_Assembly_main_building%2C_Sofia%2C_October_2016_02.jpg/220px-National_Assembly_main_building%2C_Sofia%2C_October_2016_02.jpg)](/wiki/File:National_Assembly_main_building,_Sofia,_October_2016_02.jpg) The [National Assembly](/wiki/National_Assembly_(Bulgaria) "National Assembly (Bulgaria)") building [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Party_House%2C_Sofia_%28by_Pudelek%29.JPG/220px-Party_House%2C_Sofia_%28by_Pudelek%29.JPG)](/wiki/File:Party_House,_Sofia_(by_Pudelek).JPG) The [Council of Ministers](/wiki/Government_of_Bulgaria "Government of Bulgaria") (left), [Presidency](/wiki/President_of_Bulgaria "President of Bulgaria") (right) and the former Communist Party House

Under Bulgaria's centralised political system, Sofia concentrates much of the political and financial resources of the country. It is the only city in Bulgaria to host three electoral constituencies: the [23rd](/wiki/23rd_Multi-member_Constituency "23rd Multi-member Constituency"), [24th](/wiki/24th_Multi-member_Constituency "24th Multi-member Constituency") and [25th Multi-member Constituencies](/wiki/25th_Multi-member_Constituency "25th Multi-member Constituency"), which together field 42 mandates in the 240-member National Assembly.^[\[127\]](#cite_note-128)^{#cite_ref-128}  

### Crime {#Crime}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sofia&action=edit&section=15 "Edit section: Crime")\]

With a murder rate of 1.7/per 100.000 people (as of 2009^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Sofia&action=edit)^) Sofia is a relatively safe capital city.^[\[128\]](#cite_note-129)^ Nevertheless, in the 21st century, crimes, including [Bulgarian mafia](/wiki/Bulgarian_mafia "Bulgarian mafia") killings, caused problems in the city,^[\[129\]](#cite_note-CoulbyCowen2013-130)^ where authorities had difficulties convicting the actors,^[\[130\]](#cite_note-Noutcheva2012-131)^ which had caused the [European Commission](/wiki/European_Commission "European Commission") to warn the Bulgarian government that the country would not be able to join the EU unless it curbed crime^[\[131\]](#cite_note-Economist-132)^ (Bulgaria eventually joined in 2007).^[\[132\]](#cite_note-133)^ Many of the most severe crimes are [contract killings](/wiki/Contract_killings "Contract killings") that are connected to [organised crime](/wiki/Organised_crime "Organised crime"), but these had dropped in recent years after several arrests of gang members.^[\[133\]](#cite_note-134)^ [Corruption in Bulgaria](/wiki/Crime_in_Bulgaria#Corruption "Crime in Bulgaria") also affects Sofia's authorities. According to the director of Sofia District Police Directorate, the largest share of the crimes are thefts, making up 62.4% of all crimes in the capital city. Increasing are frauds, drug-related crimes, [petty theft](/wiki/Petty_theft "Petty theft") and [vandalism](/wiki/Vandalism "Vandalism").^[\[134\]](#cite_note-135)^ According to a survey, almost a third of Sofia's residents say that they never feel safe in the Bulgarian capital, while 20% always feel safe.^[\[135\]](#cite_note-136)^ As of 2015^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Sofia&action=edit)^, the consumer-reported perceived crime risk on the [Numbeo](/wiki/Numbeo "Numbeo") database was "high" for theft and vandalism and "low" for violent crimes; safety while walking during daylight was rated "very high", and "moderate" during the night.^[\[136\]](#cite_note-Numbeo-137)^ With 1,600 prisoners, the [incarceration rate](/wiki/Incarceration_rate "Incarceration rate") is above 0.1%;^[\[137\]](#cite_note-138)^ however, roughly 70% of all prisoners are part of the [Romani minority](/wiki/Romani_people_in_Bulgaria "Romani people in Bulgaria").^[\[138\]](#cite_note-139)^{#cite_ref-139}

### Arts and entertainment {#Arts_and_entertainment}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sofia&action=edit&section=17 "Edit section: Arts and entertainment")\]  
See also: [Art galleries in Sofia](/wiki/Art_galleries_in_Sofia "Art galleries in Sofia")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Aleksander_Nevsky_Cathedral%2C_Sofia_BUL.jpg/220px-Aleksander_Nevsky_Cathedral%2C_Sofia_BUL.jpg)](/wiki/File:Aleksander_Nevsky_Cathedral,_Sofia_BUL.jpg) [Cathedral](/wiki/Cathedral "Cathedral") dedicated to [Alexander Nevsky](/wiki/Alexander_Nevsky "Alexander Nevsky")

Sofia concentrates the majority of Bulgaria's leading performing arts troupes. Theatre is by far the most popular form of performing art, and theatrical venues are among the most visited, second only to cinemas. There were 3,162 theatric performances with 570,568 people attending in 2014.^[\[139\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESofia2016159-140)^ The [Ivan Vazov National Theatre](/wiki/Ivan_Vazov_National_Theatre "Ivan Vazov National Theatre"), which performs mainly classical plays and is situated in the very centre of the city, is the most prominent theatre. The [National Opera and Ballet of Bulgaria](/wiki/National_Opera_and_Ballet_of_Bulgaria "National Opera and Ballet of Bulgaria") is a combined opera and ballet collective established in 1891. Regular performances began in 1909. Some of Bulgaria's most famous operatic singers, such as [Nicolai Ghiaurov](/wiki/Nicolai_Ghiaurov "Nicolai Ghiaurov") and [Ghena Dimitrova](/wiki/Ghena_Dimitrova "Ghena Dimitrova"), made their first appearances on the stage of the National Opera and Ballet.{#cite_ref-FOOTNOTESofia2016159_140-0}

Cinema is the most popular form of entertainment: there were more than 141,000 film shows with a total attendance exceeding 2,700,000 in 2014.^[\[140\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESofia2016160-141)^ Over the past two decades, numerous independent cinemas have closed and most shows are in shopping centre [multiplexes](/wiki/Multiplex_(movie_theater) "Multiplex (movie theater)"). *Odeon* (not part of the [Odeon Cinemas](/wiki/Odeon_Cinemas "Odeon Cinemas") chain) shows exclusively European and independent American films, as well as 20th century classics. The Boyana Film studios was at the centre of a once-thriving domestic film industry, which declined significantly after 1990. [Nu Image](/wiki/Nu_Image "Nu Image") acquired the studios to upgrade them into [Nu Boyana Film Studios](/wiki/Nu_Boyana_Film_Studios "Nu Boyana Film Studios"), used to shoot scenes for a number of action movies like *[The Expendables 2](/wiki/The_Expendables_2 "The Expendables 2")* , *[Rambo: Last Blood](/wiki/Rambo:_Last_Blood "Rambo: Last Blood")* and *[London Has Fallen](/wiki/London_Has_Fallen "London Has Fallen")* .^[\[141\]](#cite_note-142)^^[\[142\]](#cite_note-143)^{#cite_ref-143}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Museum_of_Contemporary_Art_-_Sofia_Arsenal_Front_facade%2C_%D0%A1%D0%BE%D1%84%D0%B8%D0%B9%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8_%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%81%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B0%D0%BB_-_%D0%9C%D1%83%D0%B7%D0%B5%D0%B9_%D0%B7%D0%B0_%D1%81%D1%8A%D0%B2%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%BC%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BD%D0%BE_%D0%B8%D0%B7%D0%BA%D1%83%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B2%D0%BE.jpg/220px-Museum_of_Contemporary_Art_-_Sofia_Arsenal_Front_facade%2C_%D0%A1%D0%BE%D1%84%D0%B8%D0%B9%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8_%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%81%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B0%D0%BB_-_%D0%9C%D1%83%D0%B7%D0%B5%D0%B9_%D0%B7%D0%B0_%D1%81%D1%8A%D0%B2%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%BC%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BD%D0%BE_%D0%B8%D0%B7%D0%BA%D1%83%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B2%D0%BE.jpg)](/wiki/File:Museum_of_Contemporary_Art_-_Sofia_Arsenal_Front_facade,_%D0%A1%D0%BE%D1%84%D0%B8%D0%B9%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8_%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%81%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B0%D0%BB_-_%D0%9C%D1%83%D0%B7%D0%B5%D0%B9_%D0%B7%D0%B0_%D1%81%D1%8A%D0%B2%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%BC%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BD%D0%BE_%D0%B8%D0%B7%D0%BA%D1%83%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B2%D0%BE.jpg) The Museum of Contemporary Art

Bulgaria's largest art museums are located in the central areas of the city. Since 2015, the [National Art Gallery](/wiki/National_Art_Gallery_(Bulgaria) "National Art Gallery (Bulgaria)"), located in the former [royal palace](/wiki/Royal_Palace_(Sofia) "Royal Palace (Sofia)"), the [National Gallery for Foreign Art](/wiki/National_Gallery_for_Foreign_Art "National Gallery for Foreign Art") (NGFA) and the [Museum of Contemporary Art -- Sofia Arsenal](/w/index.php?title=Museum_of_Contemporary_Art_%E2%80%93_Sofia_Arsenal&action=edit&redlink=1 "Museum of Contemporary Art – Sofia Arsenal (page does not exist)") were merged to form the [National Gallery](/wiki/National_Gallery "National Gallery"). Its largest branch is Kvadrat 500, located on the NFGA premises, where some 2,000 works are on display in twenty eight exhibition halls.^[\[143\]](#cite_note-144)^ The collections encompass diverse cultural items, from [Ashanti Empire](/wiki/Ashanti_Empire "Ashanti Empire") sculptures and [Buddhist](/wiki/Buddhism "Buddhism") art to [Dutch Golden Age](/wiki/Dutch_Golden_Age "Dutch Golden Age") painting, works by [Albrecht Dürer](/wiki/Albrecht_D%C3%BCrer "Albrecht Dürer"), [Jean-Baptiste Greuze](/wiki/Jean-Baptiste_Greuze "Jean-Baptiste Greuze") and [Auguste Rodin](/wiki/Auguste_Rodin "Auguste Rodin"). The [crypt](/wiki/Crypt "Crypt") of the Alexander Nevsky cathedral is another branch of the National Gallery. It holds a collection of Eastern Orthodox icons from the 9th to the 19th century.{#cite_ref-144}

The [National History Museum](/wiki/National_Historical_Museum_(Bulgaria) "National Historical Museum (Bulgaria)"), located in [Boyana](/wiki/Boyana "Boyana"), it has a vast collection of more than 650,000 historical items dating from Prehistory to the modern era, although only 10,000 of them are permanently displayed due to the lack of space.^[\[144\]](#cite_note-145)^ Smaller collections of historical items are displayed in the [National Archaeological Museum](/wiki/National_Archaeological_Museum_(Bulgaria) "National Archaeological Museum (Bulgaria)"), a former mosque located between the edifices of the National Bank and the Presidency. Two natural sciences museums---the [Natural History Museum](/wiki/National_Museum_of_Natural_History_(Bulgaria) "National Museum of Natural History (Bulgaria)") and [Earth and Man](/wiki/Earth_and_Man_National_Museum "Earth and Man National Museum")---display minerals, animal species (alive and [taxidermic](/wiki/Taxidermy "Taxidermy")) and rare materials. The Ethnographic Museum and the [Museum of Military History](/wiki/National_Museum_of_Military_History_(Bulgaria) "National Museum of Military History (Bulgaria)") hold large collections of Bulgarian folk costumes and armaments, respectively. The [Polytechnical Museum](/wiki/National_Polytechnical_Museum "National Polytechnical Museum") has more than 1,000 technological items on display. The [SS. Cyril and Methodius National Library](/wiki/SS._Cyril_and_Methodius_National_Library "SS. Cyril and Methodius National Library"), the foremost information repository in the country, holds some 1,800,000 books and more than 7,000,000 documents, manuscripts, maps and other items.^[\[145\]](#cite_note-146)^{#cite_ref-146}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Boyana_Church_Mural_Paintings.jpg/220px-Boyana_Church_Mural_Paintings.jpg)](/wiki/File:Boyana_Church_Mural_Paintings.jpg) Interior of the medieval [Boyana Church](/wiki/Boyana_Church "Boyana Church") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Banya_Bashi_Mosque_%2837849692391%29.jpg/220px-Banya_Bashi_Mosque_%2837849692391%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Banya_Bashi_Mosque_(37849692391).jpg) The [Banya Bashi Mosque](/wiki/Banya_Bashi_Mosque "Banya Bashi Mosque"), an example of [Ottoman architecture](/wiki/Ottoman_architecture "Ottoman architecture")

The city houses many cultural institutes such as the Russian Cultural Institute, the [Polish Cultural Institute](/wiki/Polish_Cultural_Institute "Polish Cultural Institute"), the Hungarian Institute, the Czech and the Slovak Cultural Institutes, the [Italian Cultural Institute](/wiki/Italian_Cultural_Institute "Italian Cultural Institute"), [Confucius Institute](/wiki/Confucius_Institute "Confucius Institute"), [Institut Français](/wiki/Institut_Fran%C3%A7ais "Institut Français"), [Goethe Institut](/wiki/Goethe-Institut "Goethe-Institut"), [British Council](/wiki/British_Council "British Council") and [Instituto Cervantes](/wiki/Instituto_Cervantes "Instituto Cervantes") which regularly organise temporary expositions of visual, sound and literary works by artists from their respective countries.

Some of the biggest telecommunications companies, TV and radio stations, newspapers, magazines, and web portals are based in Sofia, including the [Bulgarian National Television](/wiki/Bulgarian_National_Television "Bulgarian National Television"), [bTV](/wiki/BTV_(Bulgaria) "BTV (Bulgaria)") and [Nova TV](/wiki/Nova_Television_(Bulgaria) "Nova Television (Bulgaria)"). Top-circulation newspapers include *[24 Chasa](/wiki/24_Chasa "24 Chasa")* and *[Trud](/wiki/Dneven_Trud "Dneven Trud")*.

The [Boyana Church](/wiki/Boyana_Church "Boyana Church"), a [UNESCO](/wiki/UNESCO "UNESCO") World Heritage site, contains realistic frescoes, depicting more than 240 human images and a total 89 scenes, were painted. With their vital, humanistic realism they are a [Renaissance](/wiki/Renaissance "Renaissance") phenomenon at its culmination phase in the context of the common-European art.^[\[146\]](#cite_note-ecker-147)^{#cite_ref-ecker_147-0}  

### Tourism {#Tourism}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sofia&action=edit&section=18 "Edit section: Tourism")\]

Sofia is one of the most visited tourist destinations in Bulgaria alongside coastal and mountain resorts. Among its highlights is the [Alexander Nevsky Cathedral](/wiki/Alexander_Nevsky_Cathedral,_Sofia "Alexander Nevsky Cathedral, Sofia"), one of the symbols of Bulgaria, constructed in the late 19th century. It occupies an area of 3,170 square metres (34,122 square feet) and can hold 10,000 people.

The city center contains many remains of ancient Serdica that have been excavated and are on public display, including *Complex Ancient Serdica* , eastern gate, western gate, city walls, thermal baths, 4th c. [church of St. George Rotunda](/wiki/Church_of_St._George,_Sofia "Church of St. George, Sofia"), [amphitheatre of Serdica](/wiki/Amphitheatre_of_Serdica "Amphitheatre of Serdica"), the tombs and basilicas under the [basilica of St. Sophia](/wiki/Saint_Sophia_Church,_Sofia "Saint Sophia Church, Sofia").

[Vitosha Boulevard](/wiki/Vitosha_Boulevard "Vitosha Boulevard"), also called *Vitoshka* , is a pedestrian zone with numerous cafés, restaurants, fashion boutiques, and [luxury goods](/wiki/Luxury_good "Luxury good") stores. Sofia's [geographic location](/wiki/Geographic_coordinate_system "Geographic coordinate system"), in the foothills of the weekend retreat [Vitosha](/wiki/Vitosha "Vitosha") mountain, further adds to the city's specific atmosphere.

Sports {#Sports}
----------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sofia&action=edit&section=19 "Edit section: Sports")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/Vasil_Levski_National_Stadium_2022.jpg/220px-Vasil_Levski_National_Stadium_2022.jpg)](/wiki/File:Vasil_Levski_National_Stadium_2022.jpg) [Vasil Levski National Stadium](/wiki/Vasil_Levski_National_Stadium "Vasil Levski National Stadium")

A large number of sports clubs are based in the city. During the Communist era, most sports clubs concentrated on all-round sporting development, therefore [CSKA](/wiki/USC_CSKA_Sofia "USC CSKA Sofia"), [Levski](/wiki/Levski_Sofia_(sports_club) "Levski Sofia (sports club)"), [Lokomotiv](/wiki/PFC_Lokomotiv_Sofia "PFC Lokomotiv Sofia"), and [Slavia](/wiki/PFC_Slavia_Sofia "PFC Slavia Sofia") are dominant not only in football, but in many other team sports as well. Basketball and volleyball also have strong traditions in Sofia. A notable local [basketball](/wiki/Basketball "Basketball") team is twice [European Champions Cup](/wiki/Euroleague#Champions_1958-2008 "Euroleague") finalist [Lukoil Akademik](/wiki/PBC_Lukoil_Academic "PBC Lukoil Academic"). The [Bulgarian Volleyball Federation](/wiki/Bulgarian_Volleyball_Federation "Bulgarian Volleyball Federation") is the world's second-oldest, and it was an exhibition tournament organised by the BVF in Sofia that convinced the [International Olympic Committee](/wiki/International_Olympic_Committee "International Olympic Committee") to include volleyball as an [olympic sport](/wiki/Volleyball_at_the_Summer_Olympics#History "Volleyball at the Summer Olympics") in 1957.^[\[147\]](#cite_note-148)^ Tennis is increasingly popular in the city. There are some ten^[\[148\]](#cite_note-149)^ [tennis court](/wiki/Tennis_court "Tennis court") complexes within the city including the one founded by former [WTA](/wiki/Women%27s_Tennis_Association "Women's Tennis Association") top-five athlete [Magdalena Maleeva](/wiki/Magdalena_Maleeva "Magdalena Maleeva").^[\[149\]](#cite_note-150)^{#cite_ref-150}

Sofia applied to host the [Winter Olympic Games](/wiki/Winter_Olympic_Games "Winter Olympic Games") in 1992 and in 1994, coming second and third respectively. The city was also an applicant for the [2014 Winter Olympics](/wiki/2014_Winter_Olympics "2014 Winter Olympics"), but was not selected as candidate. In addition, Sofia hosted [EuroBasket 1957](/wiki/EuroBasket_1957 "EuroBasket 1957") and the [1961](/wiki/1961_Summer_Universiade "1961 Summer Universiade") and [1977 Summer Universiades](/wiki/1977_Summer_Universiade "1977 Summer Universiade"), as well as the [1983](/wiki/1983_Winter_Universiade "1983 Winter Universiade") and [1989 winter editions](/wiki/1989_Winter_Universiade "1989 Winter Universiade"). In 2012, it hosted the [FIVB World League](/wiki/FIVB_World_League "FIVB World League") finals.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/Garanti_Koza_Sofia_Open_-_at_Arena_Armeets.jpg/220px-Garanti_Koza_Sofia_Open_-_at_Arena_Armeets.jpg)](/wiki/File:Garanti_Koza_Sofia_Open_-_at_Arena_Armeets.jpg) Arena Sofia during the [ATP Sofia Open](/wiki/ATP_Sofia_Open "ATP Sofia Open")

The city is home to a number of large sports venues, including the 43,000-seat [Vasil Levski National Stadium](/wiki/Vasil_Levski_National_Stadium "Vasil Levski National Stadium") which hosts international football matches, as well as [Balgarska Armia Stadium](/wiki/Stadion_Balgarska_Armia "Stadion Balgarska Armia"), [Georgi Asparuhov Stadium](/wiki/Georgi_Asparuhov_Stadium "Georgi Asparuhov Stadium") and [Lokomotiv Stadium](/wiki/Lokomotiv_Stadium_(Sofia) "Lokomotiv Stadium (Sofia)"), the main venues for outdoor musical concerts. [Arena Sofia](/wiki/Arena_Sofia "Arena Sofia") holds many indoor events and has a capacity of up to 19,000 people depending on its use. The venue was inaugurated on 30 July 2011, and the first event it hosted was a friendly volleyball match between Bulgaria and Serbia. There are two [ice skating](/wiki/Ice_skating "Ice skating") complexes --- the [Winter Sports Palace](/wiki/Winter_Sports_Palace "Winter Sports Palace") with a capacity of 4,600 and the Slavia Winter Stadium with a capacity of 2,000, both containing two rinks each.^[\[150\]](#cite_note-151)^ A [velodrome](/wiki/Velodrome "Velodrome") with 5,000 seats in the city's [central park](/wiki/Borisova_gradina "Borisova gradina") is undergoing renovation.^[\[151\]](#cite_note-152)^ There are also various other sports complexes in the city which belong to institutions other than football clubs, such as those of the [National Sports Academy](/wiki/National_Sports_Academy_%22Vasil_Levski%22 "National Sports Academy \"Vasil Levski\""), the [Bulgarian Academy of Sciences](/wiki/Bulgarian_Academy_of_Sciences "Bulgarian Academy of Sciences"), or those of different universities. There are more than fifteen swimming complexes in the city, most of them outdoor.^[\[152\]](#cite_note-153)^ Nearly all of these were constructed as competition venues and therefore have seating facilities for several hundred people.{#cite_ref-153}

There are two [golf](/wiki/Golf "Golf") courses just to the east of Sofia --- in [Elin Pelin](/wiki/Elin_Pelin "Elin Pelin") (St Sofia club) and in [Ihtiman](/wiki/Ihtiman "Ihtiman") (Air Sofia club), and a horseriding club (St George club). Sofia was designated as European Capital of Sport in 2018. The decision was announced in November 2014 by the Evaluation Committee of ACES Europe, on the grounds that "the city is a good example of sport for all, as means to improve healthy lifestyle, integration and education, which are the basis of the initiative".

----------------------------
