[Historical population]

![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/timeline/inu2eqiiggmwymgoqqb3l2eu82jn1u4.png)
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/13.modelat_bay_Georgi_i_studenti_ot_akademiata.jpg/220px-13.modelat_bay_Georgi_i_studenti_ot_akademiata.jpg)](/wiki/File:13.modelat_bay_Georgi_i_studenti_ot_akademiata.jpg) Students of the [National Academy of Arts](/wiki/National_Academy_of_Arts "National Academy of Arts") (circa 1952--53). People aged 20--25 years have been the most numerous group in the city since the process of Bulgarian urbanisation.

According to 2018 data, the city has a population of 1,400,384 and the whole [Sofia Capital Municipality](/wiki/Sofia_Capital_Municipality "Sofia Capital Municipality") of 1,500,120.^[\[155\]](#cite_note-156)^ The first census carried out in February 1878 by the Russian Army recorded a population of 11,694 inhabitants including 6,560 [Bulgarians](/wiki/Bulgarians "Bulgarians"), 3,538 [Jews](/wiki/Bulgarian_Jews "Bulgarian Jews"), 839 [Turks](/wiki/Turkish_people "Turkish people"), and 737 [Romani](/wiki/Romani_people "Romani people").{#cite_ref-156}

The ratio of women per 1,000 men was 1,102. The [birth rate](/wiki/Birth_rate "Birth rate") per 1000 people was 12.3 per mile and steadily increasing in the last 5 years, the [death rate](/wiki/Mortality_rate "Mortality rate") reaching 12.1 per mile and decreasing. The natural growth rate during 2009 was 0.2 per mile, the first positive growth rate in nearly 20 years. The considerable immigration to the capital from poorer regions of the country, as well as urbanisation, are among the other reasons for the increase in Sofia's population. The [infant mortality](/wiki/Infant_mortality "Infant mortality") rate was 5.6 per 1,000, down from 18.9 in 1980. According to the 2011 census, people aged 20--24 years are the most numerous group, numbering 133,170 individuals and accounting for 11% of the total 1,202,761 people. The median age is 38 though. According to the census, 1,056,738 citizens (87.9%) are recorded as ethnic [Bulgarians](/wiki/Bulgarians "Bulgarians"), 17,550 (1.5%) as [Romani](/wiki/Romani_people_in_Bulgaria "Romani people in Bulgaria"), 6,149 (0.5%) as [Turks](/wiki/Turks_in_Bulgaria "Turks in Bulgaria"), 9,569 (0.8%) belonged to other ethnic groups, 6,993 (0.6%) do not self-identify and 105,762 (8.8%) remained with undeclared affiliation.^[\[156\]](#cite_note-157)^^[\[157\]](#cite_note-158)^{#cite_ref-158}

According to the 2011 census, throughout the whole municipality some 892,511 people (69.1%) are recorded as [Eastern Orthodox](/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox "Eastern Orthodox") Christians, 10,256 (0.8%) as [Protestant](/wiki/Protestantism_in_Bulgaria "Protestantism in Bulgaria"), 6,767 (0.5%) as [Muslim](/wiki/Islam_in_Bulgaria "Islam in Bulgaria"), 5,572 (0.4%) as [Roman Catholic](/wiki/Roman_Catholicism_in_Bulgaria "Roman Catholicism in Bulgaria"), 4,010 (0.3%) belonged to other faith and 372,475 (28.8%) declared themselves [irreligious](/wiki/Irreligious "Irreligious") or did not mention any faith. The data says that roughly a third of the total population have already earned a university degree. Of the population aged 15--64 -- 265,248 people within the municipality (28.5%) are not economically active, the unemployed being another group of 55,553 people (6%), a large share of whom have completed higher education. The largest group are occupied in trading, followed by those in the [manufacturing industry](/wiki/Manufacturing_industry "Manufacturing industry"). Within the municipality, three-quarters, or 965,328 people are recorded as having access to television at home and 836,435 (64.8%) as having internet. Out of 464,865 homes -- 432,847 have connection to the communal [sanitary sewer](/wiki/Sanitary_sewer "Sanitary sewer"), while 2,732 do not have any. Of these 864 do not have any [water supply](/wiki/Water_supply "Water supply") and 688 have other than communal. Over 99.6% of males and females aged over 9 are recorded as [literate](/wiki/Literacy "Literacy"). The largest group of the population aged over 20 are recorded to live within marriage (46.3%), another 43.8% are recorded as single and another 9.9% as having other type of coexistence/partnership, whereas not married in total are a majority and among people aged up to 40 and over 70. The people with juridical status divorced or [widowed](/wiki/Widow "Widow") are either part of the factual singles or those having another type of partnership, each of the two constitutes by around 10% of the population aged over 20. Only over 1% of the juridically married do not de facto live within marriage. The families that consist of two people are 46.8%, another 34.2% of the families are made up by three people, whereas most of the households (36.5%) consist of only one person.^[\[115\]](#cite_note-book-116)^{#cite_ref-book_116-1}

Sofia was declared the national capital in 1879. One year later, in 1880, it was the fifth-largest city in the country after [Plovdiv](/wiki/Plovdiv "Plovdiv"), [Varna](/wiki/Varna,_Bulgaria "Varna, Bulgaria"), [Ruse](/wiki/Ruse,_Bulgaria "Ruse, Bulgaria") and [Shumen](/wiki/Shumen "Shumen"). Plovdiv remained the most populous Bulgarian town until 1892 when Sofia took the lead. The city is the hot spot of internal migration, the capital population is increasing and is around 17% of the national,^[\[158\]](#cite_note-159)^ thus a small number of people with local roots remain today, they dominate the surrounding [rural suburbs](/wiki/Districts_of_Sofia "Districts of Sofia") and are called [Shopi](/wiki/Shopi "Shopi"). Shopi speak the [Western Bulgarian dialects](/wiki/Bulgarian_dialects "Bulgarian dialects").{#cite_ref-159}

Economy {#Economy}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sofia&action=edit&section=21 "Edit section: Economy")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Bulgarian_National_Bank_-_panoramio.jpg/220px-Bulgarian_National_Bank_-_panoramio.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bulgarian_National_Bank_-_panoramio.jpg) [Bulgarian National Bank](/wiki/Bulgarian_National_Bank "Bulgarian National Bank") headquarters

Sofia is ranked as Beta- [global city](/wiki/Global_city "Global city") by the [Globalization and World Cities Research Network](/wiki/Globalization_and_World_Cities_Research_Network "Globalization and World Cities Research Network").^[\[159\]](#cite_note-160)^ It is the economic hub of Bulgaria and home to most major Bulgarian and international companies operating in the country, as well as the [Bulgarian National Bank](/wiki/Bulgarian_National_Bank "Bulgarian National Bank") and the [Bulgarian Stock Exchange](/wiki/Bulgarian_Stock_Exchange_%E2%80%93_Sofia "Bulgarian Stock Exchange – Sofia"). The city is ranked 62nd among financial centres worldwide.^[\[160\]](#cite_note-GFCI-161)^ In 2015, Sofia was ranked 30th out of 300 global cities in terms of combined growth in employment and real gross domestic product (GDP) per capita, the highest one amongst cities in Southeast Europe.^[\[161\]](#cite_note-162)^ The real GDP (PPP) per capita growth at the time was 2.5% and the employment went up by 3.4% to 962,400.^[\[162\]](#cite_note-163)^ In 2015, [Forbes](/wiki/Forbes "Forbes") listed Sofia as one of the top 10 places in the world to launch a [startup business](/wiki/Startup_company "Startup company"), because of the low corporate tax (10%), the fast internet connection speeds available -- one of the fastest in the world, and the presence of several investment funds, including Eleven Startup Accelerator, LAUNCHub and Neveq.^[\[163\]](#cite_note-164)^{#cite_ref-164}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Business_Park_Sofia_view_2.jpg/220px-Business_Park_Sofia_view_2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Business_Park_Sofia_view_2.jpg) [Business Park Sofia](/w/index.php?title=Business_Park_Sofia&action=edit&redlink=1 "Business Park Sofia (page does not exist)")

The city's GDP (PPS) per capita stood at €29,600 ($33,760) in 2015, one of the highest in Southeast Europe and well above other cities in the country.^[\[164\]](#cite_note-165)^ The total nominal GDP in 2018 was 38.5 billion leva ($22.4 billion), or 33,437 leva ($19,454) per capita,^[\[165\]](#cite_note-nsi1-166)^^[\[166\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESofia201664-167)^ and average monthly wages in March 2020 were $1,071, the highest nationally.^[\[167\]](#cite_note-168)^ Services dominate the economy, accounting for 88.6% of the [gross value added](/wiki/Gross_value_added "Gross value added"), followed by industry 11.3% and agriculture 0.1%.^[\[165\]](#cite_note-nsi1-166)^^[\[168\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESofia201672-169)^{#cite_ref-FOOTNOTESofia201672_169-0}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Serdica_Center%2C_a_shopping_mall_in_Sofia_2012_PD_10.jpg/220px-Serdica_Center%2C_a_shopping_mall_in_Sofia_2012_PD_10.jpg)](/wiki/File:Serdica_Center,_a_shopping_mall_in_Sofia_2012_PD_10.jpg) [Serdika Center Sofia](/wiki/Serdika_Center_Sofia "Serdika Center Sofia")

Historically, after World War II and the era of industrialisation under socialism, the city and its surrounding areas expanded rapidly and became the most heavily industrialised region of the country, with numerous factories producing steel, pig iron, machinery, industrial equipment, electronics, trams, chemicals, textiles, and food.^[\[169\]](#cite_note-Face-170)^ The influx of workers from other parts of the country became so intense that a restriction policy was imposed, and residing in the capital was only possible after obtaining Sofianite citizenship.^[\[169\]](#cite_note-Face-170)^ However, after the political changes in 1989, this kind of citizenship was removed.{#cite_ref-Face_170-1}

The most dynamic sectors include [Information technology](/wiki/Information_technology "Information technology") (IT) and manufacturing. Sofia is a regional IT hub, ranking second among the Top 10 fastest growing tech centers in Europe in terms of annual growth of active members.^[\[170\]](#cite_note-IS_IT-171)^ The sector employs about 50,000 professionals, 30% of them involved in programming, and contributes for 14% of the city's exports.^[\[170\]](#cite_note-IS_IT-171)^ The IT sector is highly diverse and includes both multinational corporations, local companies and startups. Multinationals with major research, development, innovation and engineering centers in Sofia include the second largest global IT center of [Coca-Cola](/wiki/Coca-Cola "Coca-Cola"),^[\[171\]](#cite_note-172)^ [Ubisoft](/wiki/Ubisoft_Sofia "Ubisoft Sofia"),^[\[172\]](#cite_note-173)^ [Hewlett-Packard](/wiki/Hewlett-Packard "Hewlett-Packard"),^[\[173\]](#cite_note-174)^ [VMware](/wiki/VMware "VMware"),^[\[174\]](#cite_note-175)^ [Robert Bosch GmbH](/wiki/Robert_Bosch_GmbH "Robert Bosch GmbH"),^[\[175\]](#cite_note-176)^ [Financial Times](/wiki/Financial_Times "Financial Times"),^[\[176\]](#cite_note-177)^ [Experian](/wiki/Experian "Experian"), etc.^[\[177\]](#cite_note-178)^ Several office and tech clusters have been established across the city, including [Business Park Sofia](/w/index.php?title=Business_Park_Sofia&action=edit&redlink=1 "Business Park Sofia (page does not exist)"), Sofia Tech Park, [Capital Fort](/wiki/Capital_Fort "Capital Fort") and others.{#cite_ref-178}

Manufacturing has registered a strong recovery since 2012, increasing the exports three-fold and the employment by 52% accounting for over 70,000 jobs.^[\[178\]](#cite_note-IS_manufacturing-179)^ Supported by the city's R\&D expertise, Sofia is shifting to high value-added manufacturing including electrical equipment, precision mechanics, pharmaceuticals. There are 16 industrial and logistics parks in Sofia, some sprawling to towns in neighbouring [Sofia Province](/wiki/Sofia_Province "Sofia Province"), such as [Bozhurishte](/wiki/Bozhurishte "Bozhurishte"), [Kostinbrod](/wiki/Kostinbrod "Kostinbrod") and [Elin Pelin](/wiki/Elin_Pelin_(town) "Elin Pelin (town)").^[\[178\]](#cite_note-IS_manufacturing-179)^ Manufacturing companies include [Woodward, Inc.](/wiki/Woodward,_Inc. "Woodward, Inc."), producing airframe and industrial turbomachinery systems,^[\[179\]](#cite_note-180)^ [Festo](/wiki/Festo "Festo"), producing microsensors,^[\[180\]](#cite_note-181)^ [Visteon](/wiki/Visteon "Visteon"), development and engineering of instrument clusters, LCD displays and domain controllers,^[\[181\]](#cite_note-182)^ [Melexis](/w/index.php?title=Melexis&action=edit&redlink=1 "Melexis (page does not exist)") \[[fr](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Melexis "fr:Melexis")\], producing micro-electronic semiconductor solutions in the automotive sector,^[\[182\]](#cite_note-183)^ Sopharma, producing pharmaceuticals, the largest [Lufthansa Technik](/wiki/Lufthansa_Technik "Lufthansa Technik") maintenance facilities outside Germany etc.^[\[183\]](#cite_note-184)^{#cite_ref-184}  

Transport and infrastructure {#Transport_and_infrastructure}
------------------------------------------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sofia&action=edit&section=22 "Edit section: Transport and infrastructure")\]

With its developing infrastructure and strategic location, Sofia is a major hub for international railway and automobile transport. Three of the ten [Pan-European Transport Corridors](/wiki/Pan-European_corridors "Pan-European corridors") cross the city: [IV](/wiki/Pan-European_Corridor_IV "Pan-European Corridor IV"), [VIII](/wiki/Pan-European_Corridor_VIII "Pan-European Corridor VIII"), and [X](/wiki/Pan-European_Corridor_X "Pan-European Corridor X").^[\[184\]](#cite_note-infrastructure-185)^ All major types of transport (except [water](/wiki/Maritime_transport "Maritime transport")) are represented in the city.{#cite_ref-infrastructure_185-0}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/21.04.10_Sofia_31005_%286168607167%29.jpg/220px-21.04.10_Sofia_31005_%286168607167%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:21.04.10_Sofia_31005_(6168607167).jpg) A [Siemens Desiro](/wiki/Siemens_Desiro "Siemens Desiro") train of the Bulgarian State Railways at the Central Railway Station [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Krasno_Selo_metrostation.jpg/220px-Krasno_Selo_metrostation.jpg)](/wiki/File:Krasno_Selo_metrostation.jpg) [Krasno Selo Metro Station](/wiki/Krasno_Selo_Metro_Station "Krasno Selo Metro Station")

The [Central Railway Station](/wiki/Sofia_Central_Station "Sofia Central Station") is the primary hub for domestic and international rail transport, carried out by [Bulgarian State Railways](/wiki/Bulgarian_State_Railways "Bulgarian State Railways") (BDZ), the national rail company headquartered in the city. It is one of the main stations along [BDZ Line 1](/w/index.php?title=BDZ_Line_1&action=edit&redlink=1 "BDZ Line 1 (page does not exist)"), and a hub of Lines [2](/w/index.php?title=BDZ_Line_2&action=edit&redlink=1 "BDZ Line 2 (page does not exist)"), [5](/w/index.php?title=BDZ_Line_5&action=edit&redlink=1 "BDZ Line 5 (page does not exist)"), and [13](/w/index.php?title=BDZ_Line_13&action=edit&redlink=1 "BDZ Line 13 (page does not exist)"). Line 1 provides a connection to [Plovdiv](/wiki/Plovdiv "Plovdiv"), the second-largest city in Bulgaria, while Line 2 is the longest national railway and connects Sofia and [Varna](/wiki/Varna,_Bulgaria "Varna, Bulgaria"), the largest coastal city. Lines 5 and 13 are shorter and provide connections to [Kulata](/wiki/Kulata "Kulata") and [Bankya](/wiki/Bankya "Bankya"), respectively. Overall, Sofia has 186 km (116 miles) of railway lines.^[\[185\]](#cite_note-NSI_regional-186)^{#cite_ref-NSI_regional_186-0}

[Sofia Airport](/wiki/Sofia_Airport "Sofia Airport") handled 7,208,987 passengers in 2023.^[\[186\]](#cite_note-187)^{#cite_ref-187}

[Public transport](/wiki/Sofia_Public_Transport "Sofia Public Transport") is well-developed with [bus](/wiki/Public_buses_in_Sofia "Public buses in Sofia") (2,380 km (1,479 mi)),^[\[187\]](#cite_note-bus-188)^ [tram](/wiki/Trams_in_Sofia "Trams in Sofia") (308 km (191 mi)),^[\[188\]](#cite_note-tramway-189)^ and [trolleybus](/wiki/Trolleybuses_in_Sofia "Trolleybuses in Sofia") (193 km (120 mi))^[\[189\]](#cite_note-trolleybuses-190)^ lines running in all areas of the city.^[\[190\]](#cite_note-191)^^[\[191\]](#cite_note-192)^ The [Sofia Metro](/wiki/Sofia_Metro "Sofia Metro") became operational in January 1998 with only 5 stations and currently has four lines and 47 stations.^[\[192\]](#cite_note-subway2-193)^ As of 2022^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Sofia&action=edit)^, the system has 52 km (32 mi) of track. Six new stations were opened in 2009, two more in April 2012, and eleven more in August 2012. In 2015 seven new stations were opened and the underground extended to [Sofia Airport](/wiki/Sofia_Airport "Sofia Airport") on its Northern branch and to [Business Park Sofia](/w/index.php?title=Business_Park_Sofia&action=edit&redlink=1 "Business Park Sofia (page does not exist)") on its Southern branch. In July 2016 the [Vitosha Metro Station](/wiki/Vitosha_Metro_Station "Vitosha Metro Station") was opened on the M2 main line. A third line was opened in August 2020 and re-organisation of the previous lines lead to a 4th line being created.^[\[193\]](#cite_note-194)^ This line will complete the proposed underground system of three lines with about 65 km (40 mi) of lines.^[\[194\]](#cite_note-subway-195)^ The master plan for the Sofia Metro includes three lines with a total of 63 stations.^[\[195\]](#cite_note-196)^ Until the late 2010s route taxis ([marshrutka](/wiki/Marshrutka "Marshrutka")) provided an efficient and popular [means of transport](/wiki/Mode_of_transport "Mode of transport") by being faster than public transport, but cheaper than taxis. Their use declined with the expansion of the metro and they were gradually phased out. There are around 13,000 [taxi cabs](/wiki/Taxi "Taxi") operating in the city.^[\[196\]](#cite_note-197)^ Additionally, all-[electric vehicles](/wiki/Electric_vehicle "Electric vehicle") are available through [carsharing](/wiki/Carsharing "Carsharing") company [Spark](/w/index.php?title=Spark_(carsharing)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Spark (carsharing) (page does not exist)"), which is set to increase its fleet to 300 cars by mid-2019.^[\[197\]](#cite_note-198)^{#cite_ref-198}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Sofia_%2837536243674%29.jpg/220px-Sofia_%2837536243674%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sofia_(37536243674).jpg) Cherni Vrah Boulevard

Private automobile ownership has grown rapidly in the 1990s; more than 1,000,000 cars were registered in Sofia after 2002. The city has the 4th-highest number of automobiles per capita in the European Union at 546.4 vehicles per 1,000 people.^[\[198\]](#cite_note-199)^ The municipality was known for minor and cosmetic repairs and many streets are in a poor condition. This is noticeably changing in the past years. There are different boulevards and streets in the city with a higher amount of traffic than others. These include Tsarigradsko shose, Cherni Vrah, Bulgaria, Slivnitsa, and Todor Aleksandrov boulevards, as well as the city's ring road.^[\[199\]](#cite_note-200)^ Consequently, traffic and air pollution problems have become more severe and receive regular criticism in local media. The extension of the underground system is hoped to alleviate the city's immense traffic problems.{#cite_ref-200}

Sofia has an extensive [district heating system](/wiki/Toplofikatsiya_Sofia "Toplofikatsiya Sofia") that draws on four [combined heat and power](/wiki/Cogeneration "Cogeneration") (CHP) plants and [boiler stations](/wiki/Heating_plant "Heating plant"). Virtually the entire city (900,000 households and 5,900 companies) is centrally heated, using residual heat from [electricity generation](/wiki/Electricity_generation "Electricity generation") (3,000 MW) and gas- and oil-fired heating furnaces; total [heat capacity](/wiki/Thermal_mass "Thermal mass") is 4,640 MW. The heat distribution piping network is 900 km (559 mi) long and comprises 14,000 substations and 10,000 heated buildings.  

Education and science {#Education_and_science}
----------------------------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sofia&action=edit&section=23 "Edit section: Education and science")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Sofia_University.jpg/220px-Sofia_University.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sofia_University.jpg) [Sofia University](/wiki/Sofia_University "Sofia University") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Bulgarian-Academy-of-Sciences_4.jpg/220px-Bulgarian-Academy-of-Sciences_4.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bulgarian-Academy-of-Sciences_4.jpg) [Bulgarian Academy of Sciences](/wiki/Bulgarian_Academy_of_Sciences "Bulgarian Academy of Sciences")

Much of Bulgaria's educational capacity is concentrated in Sofia. There are 221 general, 11 special and seven arts or sports schools, 56 vocational gymnasiums and colleges, and four independent colleges.^[\[200\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESofia2016141-201)^ The city also hosts 23 of Bulgaria's 51 higher education establishments and more than 105,000 university students.^[\[201\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESofia2016148-202)^^[\[202\]](#cite_note-203)^ The [American College of Sofia](/wiki/American_College_of_Sofia "American College of Sofia"), a private secondary school with roots in a school founded by American missionaries in 1860, is among the oldest American educational institutions outside of the United States.^[\[203\]](#cite_note-ACS-204)^{#cite_ref-ACS_204-0}

A number of secondary language schools provide education in a selected foreign language. These include the [First English Language School](/wiki/First_English_Language_School "First English Language School"), [91st German Language School](/w/index.php?title=91st_German_Language_School&action=edit&redlink=1 "91st German Language School (page does not exist)"), [164th Spanish Language School](/wiki/164_GPIE_%22Miguel_de_Cervantes%22 "164 GPIE \"Miguel de Cervantes\""), and the [Lycée Français](/wiki/Lyc%C3%A9e_Fran%C3%A7ais_de_Sofia "Lycée Français de Sofia"). These are among the most sought-after secondary schools, along with [Vladislav the Grammarian 73rd Secondary School](/w/index.php?title=Vladislav_the_Grammarian_73rd_Secondary_School&action=edit&redlink=1 "Vladislav the Grammarian 73rd Secondary School (page does not exist)") and the [High School of Mathematics](/w/index.php?title=Sofia_High_School_of_Mathematics&action=edit&redlink=1 "Sofia High School of Mathematics (page does not exist)"), which topped the 2018 preference list for high school candidates.^[\[204\]](#cite_note-205)^{#cite_ref-205}

Higher education includes four of the five highest-ranking national universities -- [Sofia University](/wiki/Sofia_University "Sofia University") (SU), the [Technical University of Sofia](/wiki/Technical_University_of_Sofia "Technical University of Sofia"), [New Bulgarian University](/wiki/New_Bulgarian_University "New Bulgarian University"), and the [Medical University of Sofia](/wiki/Medical_University_of_Sofia "Medical University of Sofia").^[\[205\]](#cite_note-Webometrics-206)^ Sofia University was founded in 1888.^[\[206\]](#cite_note-207)^ More than 20,000 students^[\[207\]](#cite_note-208)^ study in its 16 faculties.^[\[208\]](#cite_note-209)^ A number of research and cultural departments operate within SU, including its own publishing house, [botanical gardens](/wiki/Botanical_garden "Botanical garden"),^[\[209\]](#cite_note-210)^ a space research centre, a [quantum electronics](/wiki/Quantum_electronics "Quantum electronics") department,^[\[210\]](#cite_note-211)^ and a [Confucius Institute](/wiki/Confucius_Institute "Confucius Institute").^[\[211\]](#cite_note-212)^ [Rakovski Defence and Staff College](/wiki/Rakovski_Defence_and_Staff_College "Rakovski Defence and Staff College"), the [National Academy of Arts](/wiki/National_Academy_of_Arts "National Academy of Arts"), the [University of Architecture, Civil Engineering and Geodesy](/wiki/University_of_Architecture,_Civil_Engineering_and_Geodesy "University of Architecture, Civil Engineering and Geodesy"), the [University of National and World Economy](/wiki/University_of_National_and_World_Economy "University of National and World Economy"), and the [University of Mining and Geology](/w/index.php?title=University_of_Mining_and_Geology&action=edit&redlink=1 "University of Mining and Geology (page does not exist)") are other major higher education establishments in the city.^[\[205\]](#cite_note-Webometrics-206)^{#cite_ref-Webometrics_206-1}

Other institutions of national significance, such as the [Bulgarian Academy of Sciences](/wiki/Bulgarian_Academy_of_Sciences "Bulgarian Academy of Sciences") (BAS) and the [SS. Cyril and Methodius National Library](/wiki/SS._Cyril_and_Methodius_National_Library "SS. Cyril and Methodius National Library"), are located in Sofia. BAS is the centrepiece of scientific research in Bulgaria, employing more than 4,500 scientists in various institutes. Its Institute of Nuclear Research and Nuclear Energy will operate the largest [cyclotron](/wiki/Cyclotron "Cyclotron") in the country.^[\[212\]](#cite_note-213)^^[\[213\]](#cite_note-214)^ All five of Bulgaria's [supercomputers](/wiki/Supercomputer "Supercomputer") and supercomputing clusters are located in Sofia as well. Three of those are operated by the BAS; one by [Sofia Tech Park](/w/index.php?title=Sofia_Tech_Park&action=edit&redlink=1 "Sofia Tech Park (page does not exist)") and one by the Faculty of Physics at Sofia University.^[\[214\]](#cite_note-215)^{#cite_ref-215}
